Events in the year '''1995 in Greece'''.
==Incumbents== * [[President of Greece|President]] – [[Konstantinos Karamanlis]] (until 10 March), [[Konstantinos Stephanopoulos]] (starting 10 March) * [[Prime Minister of Greece|Prime Minister]] – [[Andreas Papandreou]]
==Events==
===January===
===February===
===March=== * 8 March – The [[Hellenic Parliament]] elects [[Konstantinos Stephanopoulos]] as the new [[President of the Hellenic Republic]].
===April===
===May=== *13 May – The 6.6 {{M|w|link=y}} [[List of earthquakes in Greece|Kozani-Grevena earthquake]] shook the area with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (''Severe''), injuring 25 and causing $450 million in damage.
===June=== *15 June – The 6.5 {{M|w|link=y}} [[List of earthquakes in Greece|Aigio earthquake]] shook the area with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VII (''Very strong''), killing 25, injuring 60 and causing $660 million in damage.

{{Primary sources|date=July 2009}} {{Infobox company | name = Alpha Bank Skopje | logo =<!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[File:Alpha Bank.jpg]] --> | vector_logo = | type = Bank | genre = | foundation = 1993<!-- this parameter modifies "Founded" --> | founder = | location_city = [[Skopje]] | location_country = [[Republic of Macedonia]]| | location = <!-- this parameter modifies "Headquarters" --> | origins = | key_people = | area_served = | industry = [[Finance]] | products = [[Commercial bank]]ing | | operating_income = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | owner = Silk Road Capital (100%)<ref>https://www.liberal.gr/arthro/48944/oikonomia/epicheiriseis/oloklirothike-Alpha-Bank-AD-Skopje-sti-Silk-Road-Capital.html</ref> | slogan = | homepage = http://www.alphabank.com.mk | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''Alpha Bank Skopje''' (full name: Alpha Bank AD Skopje) is the subsidiary of the [[Greece|Greek]] bank [[Alpha Bank]], in the [[Republic of Macedonia]].
In 1999, Alpha Bank officially agreed on the purchase of a 65 Percent (%) stake in the Macedonian '''Kreditna Banka'''. In 2002, [[Alpha Bank]], Athens acquired the minority stake and changed its name to Alpha Bank Skopje.
==History==
In April 1993, one of the first private Banks of the country was established, then named Kreditna Banka AD Skopje.
- In January 2000, Alpha Bank, Athens acquired the majority stake in the Bank and became the main shareholder.
- In April 2002, the Bank was renamed into Alpha Bank AD Skopje, following Alpha Bank Group worldwide policy.
- In August 2002, Alpha Bank, Athens acquired the minority stake and became the sole shareholder in Alpha Bank AD Skopje, accounting for 100% of its share capital.
==See also== *[[List of banks]] *[[List of banks in Macedonia]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.alphabank.com.mk/ Official site]

'''''Around The World''''' is the third studio album released by [[Latvia]]n [[Instrumental music|instrumental]] [[cello rock]] trio [[Melo-M]]. The album is produced by trio member Kārlis Auzāns and recorded 2009 at Chellout Studios in [[Riga]], [[Latvia]]. The album consists of 12 instrumental [[cover version]] tracks and a cover version track featuring Latvian singer [[Intars Busulis]].
== Personnel == *Kārlis Auzāns (alias Charlie Lee){{snd}}cello, percussion *Valters Pūce (alias Walis Shmuls){{snd}}cello *Antons Trocjuks (alias Tonny Trolly){{snd}}cello

{{about|Atlantic Institute for International Affairs|the cross-cultural civic organization also called "Atlantic Institute"|Alliance for Shared Values}} The '''Atlantic Institute''' (full name, '''Atlantic Institute for International Affairs''') was an independent, non-governmental institute that promoted economic, political, and cultural relations among [[NATO]] alliance members and the international community in general. Based in [[Paris]], France, it was founded in 1961 and closed in 1988.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Scott-Smith |first=Giles |date=2014 |title=Maintaining Transatlantic Community: US Public Diplomacy, the Ford Foundation and the Successor Generation Concept in US Foreign Affairs, 1960s–1980s |journal=Global Society |volume=28 |issue=1 |pages=90–103 |doi=10.1080/13600826.2013.848189}}</ref>
The institute was approved by the NATO Parliamentarians Conference in June 1959 and opened formally on January 1, 1961. Former Belgian Prime Minister [[Paul van Zeeland]] was the first Chairman of the institute, while [[Henry Cabot Lodge, Jr.|Henry Cabot Lodge]] became Director-General later that year. Headquarters initially were at the [[Hôtel de Crillon]], site of the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|1919 Paris Peace Conference]]. Funding of $250,000 over five years was supplied by the [[Ford Foundation]], with a further $800,000 given between 1969 and 1973.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nato.int/acad/fellow/96-98/small.pdf |title=The Atlantic Council--The Early Years |author=[[Melvin Small]] |date=1998-06-01 |publisher=NATO}}</ref>
In 1978, talks were held to consider a merger between the Atlantic Institute and the [[Trilateral Commission]], a similar private institution promoting American, European, and Japanese cooperation,<ref>{{cite news |title=Trilateral Commission Considers Merger With Similar Paris Group |author=John M. Goshko, |date=1978-01-18 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref> but no merger proceeded.
On July 12, 1984, the offices of the Institute were bombed by the left-wing guerrilla group [[Action directe (armed group)|Action directe]], who described the institute as an "imperialist" organization working for NATO.<ref>{{cite news |title=Guerrillas Bomb Offices in Paris |work=The Philadelphia Inquirer |author=Claire Rosemberg |date=1984-07-16}}</ref>
==Notable members== *[[George Catlin (political scientist)|George Catlin]], draftsman of constitution *[[John J. McCloy]], Honorary Chairman 1966-1968 *[[Theodore Achilles]], Governor 1969-1973 *[[Martin J. Hillenbrand]], Director General 1977 - 1982 *[[George Baring, 3rd Earl of Cromer]], Governor *[[Kasım Gülek]], Governor *[[Olivier Giscard d'Estaing]], Governor
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:International organizations based in France]] [[Category:Bodies of NATO]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} The '''Australian Antarctic Division''' (AAD) is a division of the [[Department of the Environment (Australia)|Department of the Environment]]. The Division undertakes science programs and research projects to contribute to an understanding of [[Antarctica]] and the [[Southern Ocean]]. It conducts and supports collaborative research programs with other Australian and international organisations, such as the [[Bureau of Meteorology]] and [[Geoscience Australia]], as well as administering and maintaining a presence in Australian [[Australian Antarctic Territory|Antarctic]] and [[Heard Island and McDonald Islands|sub-Antarctic]] territories.
Their website includes articles on the Antarctic wildlife, threats, guidelines and they have blogs written by Australians at the three Australian bases in Antarctica: Mawson, Davis and Casey.
== Charter == Under its charter the Australian Antarctic Division: * Administers the [[Australian Antarctic Territory]] and the Territory of [[Heard Island and McDonald Islands]] * Conducts research in high priority areas of Antarctic science * Coordinates and manages Australia's logistic program in Antarctica * Promotes Antarctic research in universities through grants and the provision of logistic support * Develops policy proposals and provides advice on Australia's Antarctic interests * Promotes Australia's Antarctic interests within the [[Antarctic Treaty System]] * Maintains a continuing presence in the region through permanent stations, the establishment of field bases and the provision of transport, communication and medical services * Acts as the primary source of Australian Antarctic information
== Australian Antarctic program == The Australian Antarctic Division leads the Australian Antarctic program (AAp) with four key goals: * Maintain the Antarctic Treaty System and enhance Australia's influence in it * Protect the Antarctic environment * Understand the role of Antarctica in the global climate system * Undertake scientific work of practical, economic and national significance
== Research stations == [[File:MacquarieIslandIsthmus.JPG|thumb|Macquarie Island station in 1996]] The AAD headquarters is in [[Kingston, Tasmania|Kingston]], Tasmania, just south of [[Hobart]]. The division's headquarters houses laboratories for science, electronics and electron microscopy, mechanical and instrument workshops, a krill research aquarium, a herbarium, equipment stores, communications and other operational and support facilities. The Chief Scientist since 2016 has been Dr [[Gwen Fenton]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-12-11/dr-gwen-fenton-becomes-aads-first-female-chief-scientist/7022536|title=Gwen Fenton becomes AAD's first female chief scientist|date=11 December 2015|publisher=ABC News|access-date=15 August 2016}}</ref>
The AAD maintains three permanently manned stations on the Antarctic continent, and one on [[Macquarie Island]] in the subantarctic:<ref name=aadsta>{{cite web | url = http://www.antarctica.gov.au/living-and-working/stations | title = Stations | publisher = Australian Antarctic Division | accessdate = 16 October 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101025143219/http://www.antarctica.gov.au/living-and-working/stations| archivedate= 25 October 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
* [[Casey Station]] (including the seasonal camp at [[Wilkins Runway]]) * [[Davis Station]] * [[Mawson Station]] * [[Macquarie Island Station]]
Remote [[Antarctic field camps|field bases]] operate during the summer research season supporting coastal, inland and traverse operations.
== Transport == [[File:Aurora Australis and penguins.jpg|thumb|Researchers studying penguins while voyaging aboard the ''Aurora Australis'']]
=== Aviation === The AAD uses an air transport system, both for transport to and from Antarctica, and for transport within the continent. Aircraft for this system are provided and operated under contract by private sector operators. Services to and from Antarctica are provided, between November and February each year, by an [[Airbus A320 family|Airbus A319-115LR]] operated by [[Skytraders]]. This aircraft operates to and from the [[Wilkins Runway|Wilkins ice runway]], situated some {{convert|65|km}} from Casey Station.<ref name=awnov10>{{cite news | first = Scmitz | last = Sebastian | title = From Oz to Ice: Flight Operations of the Australia Antarctic Division | work = Airliner World | publisher = Key Publishing Ltd | date = November 2010}}</ref><ref name=aadair>{{cite web | url = http://www.antarctica.gov.au/living-and-working/travel-and-logistics/aviation | title = Aviation | publisher = Australian Antarctic Division | accessdate = 16 October 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101004145005/http://www.antarctica.gov.au/living-and-working/travel-and-logistics/aviation| archivedate= 4 October 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
Services within Antarctica are provided by a mixture of [[fixed-wing aircraft]] and [[helicopter]]s. Fixed-wing services are provided by a pair of [[CASA C-212 Aviocar|CASA 212–400]] aircraft, equipped with skis, that are also operated by Skytraders. These aircraft operate from Wilkins runway and from smaller snow runways at each of the three permanent stations, as well as any field locations which provide the necessary flat area of snow or ice. Helicopter services are provided by three [[Eurocopter AS350|Eurocopter AS 350 BA Squirrel]] helicopters, operated by [[Helicopter Resources]].<ref name=awnov10/><ref name=aadairint>{{cite web | url = http://www.antarctica.gov.au/living-and-working/travel-and-logistics/aviation/intra-continental-operations | title = Intra-continental operations | publisher = Australian Antarctic Division | accessdate = 16 October 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100929041909/http://www.antarctica.gov.au/living-and-working/travel-and-logistics/aviation/intra-continental-operations| archivedate= 29 September 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
The [[Antarctic Flight RAAF]] operated from 1948 to 1963. Since its withdrawal, aircraft from the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] operated infrequently in the Antarctic and sub-Antarctic islands in the 1970s and 1980s,<ref>{{cite web|publisher=RAAF Museum|accessdate=24 March 2010|title=Antarctic Flight|url=http://www.raaf.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/units/antarctic.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613173237/http://www.raaf.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/units/antarctic.htm|archivedate=13 June 2010}}</ref>{{sfn|Wilson|1991|pp=110–114}} and more recently in late 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=RAAF operates C-17 proof of concept flights to Antarctica|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2015/11/raaf-operates-c-17-proof-of-concept-flights-to-antarctica/|work=Australian Aviation|date=22 November 2015|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref>
=== Shipping === The AAD uses the icebreaker ''RSV [[Aurora Australis (icebreaker)|Aurora Australis]]'', a multi-purpose marine research and resupply ship chartered from [[Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company|P&O Polar]]. The ''Aurora Australis'' was launched in 1989 and built by [[Forgacs Shipyard|Carrington Slipways]] in [[Newcastle, New South Wales]].<ref name=aadauraus>{{cite web | url = http://www.antarctica.gov.au/living-and-working/travel-and-logistics/ships/aurora-australis | title = Aurora Australis | publisher = Australian Antarctic Division | accessdate = 16 October 2010}}</ref> In late October 2015 the Australian government announced a plan to acquire a new ice-breaker to replace ''Aurora Australis'' by 2019.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ikin|first1=Sam|last2=Bolger|first2= Rosemary|last3=Gamenz|first3=Emilie|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-29/pm-turnbull-releases-details-of-new-500-million-icebreaker/6893848|title=New $500 million icebreaker Australia's biggest investment the Antarctic program, Prime Minister says|publisher=ABC News|date=29 October 2015|accessdate=13 January 2016}}</ref>
== Territorial administration == The AAD is responsible, on behalf of the Australian Government, for administering the two Australian federal territories that lie in Antarctic or sub-Antarctic latitudes:
*[[Australian Antarctic Territory]] *[[Heard Island and McDonald Islands]]
Although the AAD maintains a base on [[Macquarie Island]], that island is not a federal territory but is rather part of the Australian state of [[Tasmania]].
== Notes == {{reflist|30em}}
==References== {{Refbegin}} *{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=David|year=1991|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/232/Alfresco-Flight---The-RAAF-Antartic-Experience.aspx|title=Alfresco Flight: The RAAF Antarctic Experience|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force Museum|location=Point Cook, Victoria|isbn=0-642-10522-7|ref=harv}} {{Refend}}
==External links== {{commons category|Australian Antarctic Division}} * [http://www.antarctica.gov.au/ Australian Antarctic Division website]
{{Authority control}}
[[Category:Commonwealth Government agencies of Australia]] [[Category:Scientific organisations based in Australia]] [[Category:Australian Antarctic Territory]] [[Category:Antarctic agencies]] [[Category:Australia and the Antarctic]] [[Category:Hobart]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use British English|date=September 2018}} {{short description|corporate tax avoidance tools}} {{Taxation}} [[File:Treasury Department rear view.JPG|thumb|The [[United States Department of the Treasury]] decided against signing the 2016 OECD anti–BEPS MLI initiative from the {{slink|#OECD BEPS Project}}, stating that the U.S.: "has a low degree of exposure to base erosion and profit shifting". International tax academics showed in 2018 that U.S. multinationals are the largest users of BEPS tools in the world; while U.S tax academics demonstrated, even as early as 1994, that the U.S. exchequer is a net beneficiary from the use of tax havens and BEPS by U.S. multinationals.]] '''Base erosion and profit shifting''' or '''BEPS''' refers to corporate [[tax planning]] strategies used by [[multinational companies|multinationals]] to "shift" profits from higher–tax jurisdictions to lower–tax jurisdictions, thus "eroding" the "tax–base" of the higher–tax jurisdictions.{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/|title=OECD Base Erosion and Profit Shifting}} The OECD defines BEPS strategies as also: "exploiting gaps and mismatches in tax rules";{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/|title=OECD Base Erosion and Profit Shifting}} however, academics proved corporate [[tax havens]] (e.g. Ireland, the Caribbean, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Singapore, Switzerland, and Hong Kong),{{efn|These are also the largest [[offshore financial centres]] ("OFCs"); a term considered by academics to be synonymous with the term [[tax haven]]}} who are the largest [[Corporate haven#Global BEPS hubs|global BEPS hubs]], use OECD–whitelisted tax structures and OECD–compliant BEPS tools. [[Corporate tax haven]]s offer BEPS tools to "shift" profits to the haven, and additional BEPS tools to avoid paying taxes within the haven (e.g. Ireland's "[[Ireland as a tax haven#Green Jersey|Green Jersey]]").{{efn|''Green Jersey'' was the BEPS tool Apple used in Q1 2015 to restructure its non–U.S. IP. It created the famous "[[leprechaun economics]]" event in Ireland in August 2016, when restated Irish GDP rose 34.4% in a single quarter}} BEPS tools are mostly associated with U.S. [[technology]] and [[life science]] multinationals.{{efn|name="ip"|The critical component of the most important BEPS tools is [[intellectual property]] ("IP"), which the BEPS tool converts into a charge that is deductible against pre–tax income. Technology and Life Sciences industries have the largest pools of IP.}} Tax academics showed use of BEPS tools by U.S. multinationals, via [[tax havens]], maximised long–term U.S. exchequer receipts and/or shareholder returns, at the expense of other jurisdictions. ==Source and scale== A January 2017 OECD report estimates that BEPS tools are responsible for tax losses of circa $100–240 billion per annum.{{cite web|title=BEPS Project Background Brief| url=http://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/background-brief-inclusive-framework-for-beps-implementation.pdf|publisher=[[OECD]]|quote=With a conservatively estimated annual revenue loss of USD 100 to 240 billion, the stakes are high for governments around the world. The impact of BEPS on developing countries, as a percentage of tax revenues, is estimated to be even higher than in developed countries.|date=January 2017|page=9}} A June 2018 report by tax academic [[Gabriel Zucman]] (et alia),{{cite web|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/missingprofits/|title=The Missing Profits of Nations|quote=Appendix Table 2: Tax Havens|page=31|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|author2=Thomas Torslov|author3=Ludvig Wier|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers|date=June 2018}} estimated that the figure is closer to $200 billion per annum.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporations-push-profits-into-tax-havens-as-countries-struggle-in-pursuit-study-says-1528634659|title=Zucman:Corporations Push Profits Into Corporate Tax Havens as Countries Struggle in Pursuit, Gabrial Zucman Study Says|quote=Such profit shifting leads to a total annual revenue loss of $200 billion globally|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=10 June 2018}} The [[Tax Justice Network]] estimated that profits of $660 billion were "shifted" in 2015 (due to Apple's Q1 2015 [[leprechaun economics]] restructuring, the largest individual BEPS transaction in history).{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/Tax-dodging-the-scale-of-the-problem-TJN-Briefing.pdf|title=Tax avoidance and evasion: The scale of the problem|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=17 November 2017}}{{cite web|title=The scale of Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS): Tax Justice Network|url=http://www.taxjustice.net/scalebeps/|website=[[Tax Justice Network]]}} The effect of BEPS tools is most felt in developing economies, who are denied the tax revenues needed to build infrastructure.{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2017/09/11/new-un-tax-handbook-sets-lower-income-countries-oecd-beps/|title=New UN tax handbook: Lower–income countries vs OECD BEPS failure|publisher=Tax Justice Network| date=11 September 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/nov/08/tax-havens-dodging-theft-multinationals-avoiding-tax|title=The desperate inequality behind global tax dodging|work=The Guardian| date=8 November 2017}} Most BEPS activity is associated with industries with [[intellectual property]] ("IP"), namely Technology (e.g. Apple, Google, Microsoft, Oracle), and Life Sciences (e.g. Allergan, Medtronic, Pfizer and Merck & Co) (see [[double Irish#US multinationals using Irish tax schemes|here]]).{{efn|name="ip"}}{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2018/07/24/progress-global-profit-shifting/|title=Progress on global profit shifting: no more hiding for jurisdictions that sell profit shifting at the expense of others|date=24 July 2018|author=Alex Cobham|quote=..for US multinationals, the real explosion in profit shifting began in the 1990s. At this point, a ‘mere’ 5–10% of global profits were declared away from the jurisdictions of the underlying real economic activity. By the early 2010s, that had soared to 25–30% of global profits, with an estimated revenue loss of around $130 billion a year..|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]}} IP is described as the ''raw materials of tax avoidance'', and [[Corporate haven#IP-based BEPS tools|IP–based BEPS tools]] are responsible for the largest global BEPS income flows.{{cite web | url=https://www.uclalawreview.org/pdf/62-1-1.pdf | title=Intellectual Property Law Solutions to Tax Avoidance | author=Andrew Blair-Stanek|quote=Intellectual property (IP) has become the leading tax-avoidance vehicle.| publisher=UCLA Law Review |year=2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.fordhamiplj.org/2016/08/30/ip-tax-avoidance-ireland/ | title=Intellectual Property and Tax Avoidance in Ireland | publisher=[[Fordham Intellectual Property, Media & Entertainment Law Journal]] | date=30 August 2016}} Corporate tax havens have some of the most [[Corporate haven#The "Knowledge Economy"|advanced IP tax leglislation]] in their statutate books. Most BEPS activity is also most associated with U.S. multinationals,{{cite web | url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporations-push-profits-into-tax-havens-as-countries-struggle-in-pursuit-study-says-1528634659|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|author= Richard Rubin|quote=U.S. companies are the most aggressive users of profit-shifting techniques, which often relocate paper profits without bringing jobs and wages, according to the study by economists Thomas Torslov and Ludvig Wier of the University of Copenhagen and Gabriel Zucman of the University of California, Berkeley|date=10 June 2018|title=Corporations Push Profits Into Tax Havens as Countries Struggle in Pursuit, Study Says}}{{cite web|url=https://nordic.businessinsider.com/new-research-finds-40-of-multinationals-profits-shifted-to-tax-havens--eu-biggest-loser-while-us-firms-most-shifty--/|publisher=[[Business Insider]]|title=New research finds 40% of multinationals’ profits shifted to tax havens – EU biggest loser while US firms most shifty|date=20 July 2018}} and is attributed to the historical U.S. "worldwide" corporate taxation system.{{cite journal| url = https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2831&context=articles|title=Multinational Firms and Tax Havens|author1=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|author2=Anna Gumpert|author3=Monika Schnitzer|year=2016|journal=[[The Review of Economics and Statistics]]|page=714|quote=Germany taxes only 5% of the active foreign business profits of its resident corporations. [..] Furthermore, German firms do not have incentives to structure their foreign operations in ways that avoid repatriating income. Therefore, the tax incentives for German firms to establish tax haven affiliates are likely to differ from those of U.S. firms and bear strong similarities to those of other G-7 and OECD firms.|volume=98|issue=4}} Pre the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]] ("TCJA"), the U.S. was one of only eight jurisdictions to operate a "worldwide" tax system.{{cite web|url=https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/wp/2013/wp13205.pdf|title=Territorial vs. Worldwide Corporate Taxation: Implications for Developing Countries|publisher=IMF|year=2013|page=4}} Most global jurisdictions operate a "territorial" corporate tax system with lower tax rates for foreign sourced income, thus avoiding the need to "shift" profits (i.e. IP can be charged directly from the home country at preferential rates and/or terms; the TCJA now enables this in the U.S. with the FDII–regime).{{cite web|url=https://files.taxfoundation.org/legacy/docs/TaxFoundation_FF442.pdf | title=Tax Reform in the UK Reversed the Tide of Corporate Tax Inversions | publisher=Tax Foundation| date=14 October 2014}}{{cite web|url= https://taxfoundation.org/tax-reform-uk-reversed-tide-corporate-tax-inversions/|title=How Tax Reform solved UK inversions|publisher=Tax Foundation|date=14 October 2014}}{{cite web|url= https://taxfoundation.org/united-kingdom-s-experience-inversions/|title=The United Kingdom’s Experience with Inversions|publisher=Tax Foundation|date=5 April 2016}} {{quote|U.S. multinationals use tax havens{{efn|The paper lists tax havens as: ''Ireland, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Switzerland, Singapore, Bermuda and Caribbean havens'' (page 6.)}} more than multinationals from other countries which have kept their controlled foreign corporations regulations. No other non–haven OECD country records as high a share of foreign profits booked in tax havens as the United States. [...] This suggests that half of all the global profits shifted to tax havens are shifted by U.S. multinationals. By contrast, about 25% accrues to E.U. countries, 10% to the rest of the OECD, and 15% to developing countries (Tørsløv et al., 2018).|source=[[Gabriel Zucman]], Thomas Wright, "THE EXORBITANT TAX PRIVILEGE", [[National Bureau of Economic Research|NBER]] Working Papers (September 2018).{{cite journal|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/WrightZucman2018.pdf|title=THE EXORBITANT TAX PRIVILEGE|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]]|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|page=11|author2=Thomas Wright|date=September 2018}}}} Research in June 2018, identified Ireland as the world's largest BEPS hub. Ireland is larger than the ''aggregate'' Caribbean tax haven BEPS system.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/ireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Fireland-is-the-world-s-biggest-corporate-tax-haven-say-academics-1.3528401|title=Ireland is the world’s biggest corporate ‘tax haven’, say academics|quote=New Gabriel Zucman study claims State shelters more multinational profits than the entire Caribbean|work=The Irish Times|date=13 June 2018}} The largest global BEPS hubs, from the [[Gabriel Zucman#Zucman-Tørsløv-Wier 2018 list|Zucman–Tørsløv–Wier]] table below, are synonymous with the [[Tax haven#Top 10 tax havens|top 10 global tax havens]]: {{anchor|Table 1}} [[File:Where do U.S. multinationals book their profits (2016 BEA).png|thumb|upright=1.6|U.S. multinationals book over half of their non–U.S. profits in tax havens by using BEPS tools (2016 [[Bureau of Economic Analysis|BEA]]).]] {| style="font-size:100%;" |- | width="50%" align="left" | |- valign="top" | {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ style="text-align: left;" | Zucman–Tørsløv–Wier. ''Missing Profits of Nations''. Table 1: Shifted Profits (2015){{cite web|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/|title=The Missing Profits of Nations|page=31|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|author2=Thomas Torslov|author3=Ludvig Wier|quote=Table 2: Shifted Profits: Country–by–Country Estimates (2015)|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers|date=June 2018}} |- ! style="background:#cfc;width:120px;text-align:left" | Profits Shifted
(2015 $ bn) ! style="width:190px;text-align:left" | Jurisdiction ! style="width:200px;text-align:left" | Headline Corporate Tax Rate
(all firms) ! style="width:200px;text-align:left" | Effective Corporate Tax Rate
(foreign firms) |- | 106 || align="left" | Ireland || 12.5% || 4% |- | 97 || align="left" | Caribbean† (ex. Bermuda)|| <3% || 2% |- | 70 || align="left" | Singapore || 17% || 8% |- | 58 || align="left" | Switzerland || 21% || 16% |- | 57 || align="left" | Netherlands || 25% || 10% |- | 47 || align="left" | Luxembourg || 29% || 3% |- | 39 || align="left" | Hong Kong || 18% || 18% |} |- valign="top" |} (†) Mostly consists of The Cayman Islands and The British Virgin Islands Research in September 2018, by the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]], using repatriation tax data from the TCJA, said that: "In recent years, about half of the foreign profits of U.S. multinationals have been booked in tax haven affiliates, most prominently in Ireland (18%), Switzerland, and Bermuda plus Caribbean tax havens (8%–9% each). One of the authors of this research was also quoted as saying: “Ireland solidifies its position as the #1 tax haven.”; and also that: “U.S. firms book more profits in Ireland than in China, Japan, Germany, France & Mexico combined. Irish tax rate: 5.7%.”{{cite web|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/09/11/business/half-u-s-foreign-profits-booked-tax-havens-especially-ireland-paper/#.W5eRKkZKhPY|title=Half of U.S. foreign profits booked in tax havens, especially Ireland: NBER paper|publisher=''[[The Japan Times]]''|quote=“Ireland solidifies its position as the #1 tax haven,” Zucman said on Twitter. “U.S. firms book more profits in Ireland than in China, Japan, Germany, France & Mexico combined. Irish tax rate: 5.7%.”|date=10 September 2018}} ==Tools and techniques== {{main|Corporate haven#Global BEPS hubs}} Research identifies three main BEPS techniques used for "shifting" profits to a [[corporate tax haven]] via OECD–compliant BEPS tools:{{cite web|url=http://ftp.zew.de/pub/zew-docs/dp/dp13078.pdf|title=Profit Shifting and "Aggressive" Tax Planning by Multinational Firms|publisher=[[Zentrum für Europäische Wirtschaftsforschung|Centre for European Economic Research]], (ZEW)|author1=Clemens Fuest|author2=Christoph Spengel|author3=Katharina Finke|author4=Jost Heckemeyer|author5=Hannah Nusser|date=15 October 2013}}{{cite web | url=http://arno.uvt.nl/show.cgi?fid=143915| title=Intellectual Property Tax Planning in the light of Base Erosion and Profit Shifting | publisher=University of Tilburg | date=June 2017}} {{ordered list|type=lower-roman |[[Corporate haven#IP-based BEPS tools|IP–based BEPS tools]],{{efn|name="IP"|Some academics consider IP–based BEPS tools to be a subset of TP–based BEPS tools (e.g. the corporate is transfer pricing the IP like any other product), however others consider IP to be a unique item (e.g. the IP is a ''virtual product'' whose value is decided internally by the corporation; it is more of an accounting invention rather than a tangible good), that it is a separate set.}} which enable the profits to be extracted via the cross–border charge–out of internal virtual IP assets (known as "intergroup IP charging"); and/or |[[Corporate haven#Debt-based BEPS tools|Debt–based BEPS tools]], which enable the profits to be extracted via the cross–border charge–out artificially high interest (known as "earnings stripping"); and/or |[[TP–based BEPS tools]],{{efn|name="IP"}} shifts profits to the haven by asserting that a ''process'' performed in the haven (e.g., [[contract manufacturing]]), justifies a large increase in the [[Transfer pricing|transfer price]] ("TP") at which the finished product is charged–out by the haven to higher–tax jurisdictions. }} BEPS tools could not function if the corporate tax haven did not have a network of bilateral tax treaties that accept the haven’s BEPS tools, which "shift" the profits to the haven. Modern corporate tax havens, who are the main global BEPS hubs, have extensive networks of bilateral tax treaties.{{cite journal| url=https://academic.oup.com/oxrep/article/24/4/661/547359#|title=What Problems and Opportunities are Created by Tax Havens?|author=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]]|journal=[[Oxford Review of Economic Policy]]|page=3|date=December 2008|volume=24|issue=4}} The U.K. is the leader with over 122, followed by the Netherlands with over 100.{{cite journal|title=The Tax Treaty Network of the United Kingdom|url =http://www.fieldtax.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/2013-9-ILT-247-The-Tax-Treaty-Network-of-the-United-Kingdom1.pdf|journal=International Taxation|volume=9|issue=13|quote=The United Kingdom has 122 bilateral, comprehensive, double taxation conventions in force. It remains the largest number of tax treaties of any one country in the world. The United Kingdom may no longer be the world leader in manufacturing cars, or in playing football [..] however we are still the leading country in the world in negotiating double taxation conventions.|author=Philip Baker OBE QC|date=September 2013}}{{Cite web|title = UK tops global table of damaging tax deals with developing countries|url =https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/feb/23/uk-tops-global-table-of-damaging-tax-deals-with-developing–countries|work=The Guardian|date=23 February 2016}} The ''blacklisting'' of a corporate tax haven is a serious event, which is why major BEPS hubs are OECD-compliant. Ireland was the first major corporate tax haven to be ''blacklisted'' by a G20 economy; Brazil, in September 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ireland-brazil-funds/blacklisted-by-brazil-dublin-funds-find-new-ways-to-invest-idUSL8N1MK2NX|title=Blacklisted by Brazil, Dublin funds find new ways to invest|agency=Reuters|date=20 March 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/2017/04/10/tax-haven-blacklisting-13-latin-american-countries/|title=Tax haven blacklisting in Latin America|publisher=Tax Justice Network|date=6 April 2017}} An important academic study in July 2017 published in ''[[Nature (Magazine)|Nature]]'', "[[Conduit and Sink OFCs]]", showed that the pressure to maintain OECD–compliance had split corporate–focused tax havens into two different classifications: [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Sink OFC|Sink OFCs]], which act as the ''terminus'' for BEPS flows, and [[Conduit and Sink OFCs#Conduit OFC|Conduit OFCs]], which act as the ''conduit'' for flows from higher–tax locations to the Sink OFCs. It was noted that the 5 major Conduit OFCs, namely, Ireland, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Singapore and Switzerland, all have a top–ten ranking in the 2018 ''[[Global Intellectual Property Center|Global Innovation Property Centre]] (GIPC) IP Index".{{cite web|url=http://www.theglobalipcenter.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/GIPC_IP_Index_2018.pdf|title=GIPC IP Index 2018|date=February 2018|author=[[United States Chamber of Commerce]]|quote=Figure I: U.S. Chamber International IP Index 2018, Overall Scores|page=6}} [[File:Pre-Tax Profits of U.S. foreign subsidiaries (2015 BEA Data).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.6|Profitability of U.S. subsidiaries (2015 [[Bureau of Economic Analysis|BEA]] data).]] Once profits are "shifted" to the corporate tax haven (or Conduit OFC), additional tools are used to avoid paying ''headline'' tax rates in the haven. Some of these tools are OCED–compliant (e.g. [[patent box]]es, [[double Irish arrangement#Backstop of capital allowances|Capital Allowances for Intangible Assets]] ("CAIA") or "[[Ireland as a tax haven#Green Jersey|Green Jersey]]"), others became OECD–proscribed (e.g. [[Double Irish]] and [[Corporate haven#Dutch "Double Dip"|Dutch Double–Dipping]]), while others have not attracted OECD attention (e.g. [[double Irish arrangement#Replacement by single malt|Single Malt]]). Because of the need for BEPS hubs (or Conduit OFCs) to have extensive bilateral [[tax treaties]] (e.g. so that their BEPS tools will be accepted by the higher–tax locations), they go to great lengths to obscure the fact that ''effective tax rates'' paid by multinationals in their jurisdiction are close to zero percent, rather than the ''headline'' corporate tax rate of the haven (see [[#Table 1|Table 1]]). Higher–tax jurisdictions do not enter into full bilateral tax treaties with obvious tax havens (e.g. the Cayman Islands, a major Sink OFC). This is achieved with [[Financial Secrecy Index|financial secrecy]] laws, and by the avoidance of ''country–by–country reporting'' ("CbCr") or the need to file public accounts, by multinationals in the haven's jurisdiction. BEPS hubs (or Conduit OFCs) strongly deny they are corporate tax havens, and that their use of IP is as a tax avoidance tool.{{cite web|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/business/banking/spore-is-no-tax-haven-govt-experts-here|title=MOF rejects claim of Singapore as tax haven|work=The Straits Times|date=14 December 2016}} They call themselves "[[Corporate haven#The "Knowledge Economy"|knowledge economies]]".{{Cite web|title=Singapore's government says it's not a tax haven, it's a value–adding IP hub|url = https://www.smh.com.au/business/singapores-government-says-its-not-a-tax-haven-its-a-valueadding-hub-20150430-1mwvdu.html|work=Sydney Morning Hearald|date=30 April 2015}} {{quote|Make no mistake: the headline rate is not what triggers tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. That comes from schemes that facilitate profit shifting.|source=[[Pierre Moscovici]], EU Commissioner on Taxation, Financial Times, 11 March 2018{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/2b356956-17fc-11e8-9376-4a6390addb44|title=Multinationals pay lower taxes than a decade ago|work=Financial Times|date=11 March 2018}}}} The complex accounting tools, and the detailed tax legislation, that corporate tax havens require to become OECD–compliant BEPS hubs, requires both advanced international tax–law professional services firms, and a high degree of coordination with the State, who encode their BEPS tools into the State's statutory legislation.{{cite web | url=https://maketaxfair.net/decorrespondent-reveals-netherlands-became-tax-haven/| title=DE CORRESPONDENT REVEALS HOW THE NETHERLANDS BECAME TAX HAVEN|publisher=Oxfam/De Correspondant|date=May 2017}}{{Cite web|title = The Professionals: Dealing with the enablers of tax avoidance and financial crime|url = https://www.taxjustice.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/The-Enablers-of-Tax-Avoidance-TJN-Briefing.pdf|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=November 2017|author=George Turner}} Tax investigators call such jurisdictions "[[Ireland as a tax haven#Captured state|captured states]]",{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/jan/09/explainer-what-is-tax-haven|quote=This political capture produces one of the great offshore paradoxes: these zones of ultra–freedom are often highly repressive places, wary of scrutiny and intolerant of criticism.|title=Explainer: what is a tax haven? The most important feature of a secrecy jurisdiction is that local politics is captured by financial services interests|work=The Guardian|date=9 January 2011}}{{cite web|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/tag/captured-state/|title=Tax Justice Network: Captured State|publisher=Tax Justice Network|date=November 2015}}{{Cite web|title=Revealed: Project Goldcrest, how Amazon worked with the Luxembourg Government to avoid huge sums in tax with IP|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/feb/18/revealed-project-goldcrest-amazon-avoid-huge-sums-tax|work=The Guardian|date=18 February 2016}} and explain that most leading BEPS hubs started as established [[financial centres]], where the necessary skills and State support for tax avoidance tools, already existed.{{cite journal | title=Tax haven networks and the role of the Big 4 accountancy firms|author1=Alex Cobham|author2=Chris Jones|author3=Yama Temouri|url=https://www.taxjustice.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/JWB-Big-4-Jones-Temouri-Cobham-2017.pdf|journal=Journal of World Business|quote=Our key findings demonstrate that there is a strong correlation and causal link between the size of an MNE’s tax haven network and their use of the Big 4|year=2017}}{{Cite web|title=How Ireland became an offshore financial centre|url = https://www.taxjustice.net/2015/11/11/how-ireland-became-an-offshore-financial-centre/|author=[[Nicholas Shaxson]]|publisher=[[Tax Justice Network]]|date=November 2015}} ==Complex agendas== {{main|Ireland as a tax haven#Political compromises}} {{see also|Tax haven#Benefits of tax havens}} [[File:James R. Hines Jr. C-SPAN.jpg|thumb|[[James R. Hines Jr.]] testifying to the Senate Finance Committee on Corporate Taxation in 2016. Hines is the most cited academic on research into tax havens.{{cite web|url=https://ideas.repec.org/cgi-bin/htsearch?form=extended&wm=wrd&dt=range&ul=&q=tax+haven&cmd=Search%21&wf=4BFF&s=C&db=&de=|title=IDEAS/RePEc Database|quote=Tax Havens by Most Cited}} His [[James R. Hines Jr.#Hines-Rice paper|1994 Hines–Rice paper]] is the most cited paper in all tax haven research, and its insight that the U.S. could benefit from allowing its multinationals to use tax havens and ''profit shifting'' tools, dictated U.S. tax policy for decades.]] The BEPS tools used by tax havens have been known and discussed for decades in Washington.{{cite web|url=https://www.gao.gov/assets/290/284522.pdf|title=INTERNATIONAL TAXATION: Large U.S. Corporations and Federal Contractors with Subsidiaries in Jurisdictions Listed as Tax Havens or Financial Privacy Jurisdictions|publisher=U.S. GAO |quote=Table 1: Jurisdictions Listed as Tax Havens or Financial Privacy Jurisdictions and the Sources of Those Jurisdictions | page=12 | date=18 December 2008}} For example, when Ireland was pressured by the EU-OECD to close its double Irish BEPS tool, the largest in history, to new entrants in January 2015,{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ba95cff0-4fcd-11e4-a0a4-00144feab7de | title=Brussels in crackdown on ‘double Irish’ tax loophole| work=Financial Times| date=October 2014}} existing users, which include Google and Facebook, were given a 5-year extension to 2020.{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/irelands-move-to-close-the-double-irish-tax-loophole-unlikely-to-bother-apple-google-33011 | title=Ireland’s move to close the ‘double Irish’ tax loophole unlikely to bother Apple, Google| work=The Guardian| date=October 2014}} Even before 2015, Ireland had already publicly replaced the double Irish with two new BEPS tools: the single malt (as used by Microsoft and Allergan), and capital allowances for intangible assets ("CAIA"), also called the "Green Jersey", (as used by Apple in Q1 2015).{{Cite web|title = Multinationals replacing 'Double Irish' with new tax avoidance scheme|url = https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2017/1114/919979-multinationals-using-new-arrangement-to-reduce-tax-bill/|publisher = RTÉ News|date = 14 November 2017}}{{Cite web|title = How often is the 'Single Malt' tax loophole used? The government is finding out|url = http://www.thejournal.ie/single-malt-tax-evasion-3698512-Nov2017/|website = thejournal.ie|date = 15 November 2017}} None of these new BEPS tools have been as yet proscribed by the OECD.{{cite web|url=https://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/TWZ2017.pdf|title=€600 billion and counting: Why high-tax locations let tax havens flourish|date=November 2017|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|author2=Thomas Tørsløv|author3=Ludvig Wier|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers}} Tax experts show that disputes between higher-tax jurisdictions and tax havens are very rare.{{cite web|title=The Policy Failure of High-Tax Countries|pages=44–49|url=http://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/TWZ2018Slides.pdf|publisher=[[National Bureau of Economic Research]], Working Papers|author1=[[Gabriel Zucman]]|author2=Thomas Torslov|author3=Ludvig Wier |date=June 2018}} Tax experts describe a more complex picture of an implicit acceptance by Washington that U.S. multinationals could use BEPS tools on non–U.S. earnings to offset the very high U.S. 35% corporate tax rate from the historical U.S. "worldwide" corporate tax system (see [[Ireland as a tax haven#Source of contradictions|source of contradictions]]).{{cite web|title=Tax havens: how globalization really works: Ronen Palan, Richard Murphy and Christian Chavagneux|url=https://academic.oup.com/joeg/article-abstract/11/4/753/918739?redirectedFrom=fulltext#|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|author1=[[Ronen Palan]]|author2=[[Richard Murphy (tax campaigner)|Richard Murphy]]|date=1 July 2011}} Other tax experts, including a founder of academic tax haven research, [[James R. Hines Jr.]], note that U.S. multinational use of BEPS tools and corporate tax havens had actually increased the long–term tax receipts of the U.S. exchequer, at the expense of other higher–tax jurisdictions, making the [[Tax haven#U.S. as the largest beneficiary|U.S a major beneficiary of BEPS tools and corporate-tax havens]].{{cite journal|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/j.1475-679X.2009.00346.x|title=Using Financial Accounting Data to Examine the Effect of Foreign Operations Located in Tax Havens and Other Countries on US Multinational Firms' Tax Rates|author1=Scott Dyreng|author2=Bradley P. Lindsey|date=12 October 2009|quote=Finally, we find that US firms with operations in some tax haven countries have higher federal tax rates on foreign income than other firms. This result suggests that in some cases, tax haven operations may increase US tax collections at the expense of foreign country tax collections.|journal=[[Journal of Accounting Research]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/special-report/2000/01/27/gimme-shelter|title=Gimme shelter - A survey of globalisation and tax|work=[[The Economist]]|date=27 January 2000}} {{quote|Lower foreign tax rates entail smaller credits for foreign taxes and greater ultimate U.S. tax collections (Hines and Rice, 1994). Dyreng and Lindsey (2009), offer evidence that U.S. firms with foreign affiliates in certain tax havens pay lower pay lower foreign taxes and higher U.S. taxes than do otherwise-similar large U.S. companies.|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]] |source="Treasure Islands" p. 107 (2010){{cite journal|url=https://repository.law.umich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.ie/&httpsredir=1&article=1716&context=articles|title=Treasure Islands|page=103-125|author=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|quote=Lower foreign tax rates entail smaller credits for foreign taxes and greater ultimate U.S. tax collections (Hines and Rice, 1994). Dyreng and Lindsey (2009), offer evidence that U.S. firms with foreign affiliates in certain tax havens pay lower pay lower foreign taxes and higher U.S. taxes than do otherwise-similar large U.S. companies|journal=[[Journal of Economic Perspectives]]|volume=4|issue=24|date=2010}}}} The [[James R. Hines Jr.#Tax haven research|1994 Hines–Rice paper]]{{cite journal|url=http://taxdoctoralseminar.web.unc.edu/files/2016/02/Hines-Rice.pdf|title=FISCAL PARADISE: FOREIGN TAX HAVENS AND AMERICAN BUSINESS |author1=[[James R. Hines Jr.]]|author2=Eric M. Rice|quote=We identify 41 countries and regions as tax havens for the purposes of U. S. businesses. Together the seven tax havens with populations greater than one million (Hong Kong, Ireland, Liberia, Lebanon, Panama, Singapore, and Switzerland) account for 80 percent of total tax haven population and 89 percent of tax haven GDP. |journal=[[Quarterly Journal of Economics]] (Harvard/MIT)|date=February 1994|volume=9|issue=1}} on U.S. multinational use of tax havens was the first to use the term ''profit shifting''.{{cite web|url=https://chicagounbound.uchicago.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2385&context=law_and_economics|title=What Do We Know About Base Erosion and Profit Shifting? A Review of the Empirical Literature|publisher=[[University of Chicago]]|author=[[Dhammika Dharmapala]]|year=2014|quote= It focuses particularly on the dominant approach within the economics literature on income shifting, which dates back to Hines and Rice (1994) and which we refer to as the “Hines–Rice” approach.|page=1}} Hines–Rice concluded that: ''low foreign tax rates [from tax havens] ultimately enhance U.S. tax collections''. For example, the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]] ("TCJA") levied 15.5% on the untaxed offshore cash reserves built up by U.S. multinationals with BEPS tools from 2004–2017. Had these U.S. multinationals not used BEPS tools, and paid their full foreign taxes, their foreign tax credits would have removed most of their residual exposure to any U.S. tax liability, under the U.S. tax code. The U.S. was one of the only major developed nations not to sign up to the 2016 {{slink|#OECD BEPS Project}} to curtail BEPS tools. ==OECD BEPS Project== {{see also|Base erosion and profit shifting (OECD project)}} The [[2012 G20 Los Cabos summit]] tasked the OECD to develop a ''BEPS Action Plan'',{{cite web|url=https://www.oecd.org/ctp/BEPSActionPlan.pdf|title=Action Plan on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting|publisher=OECD|year=2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/ctp/beps.htm|title=Base Erosion and Profit Shifting|work=''oecd.org''}} which [[2013 G-20 St. Petersburg summit]] approved.{{cite web |publisher=St Petersburg Tax Annex OECD |date=September 2013 |url=http://www.mofa.go.jp/files/000013928.pdf |title=TAX ANNEX TO THE SAINT PETERSBURG G20 LEADERS DECLARATION}} An OECD BEPS [[Multilateral Convention to Implement Tax Treaty Related Measures to Prevent Base Erosion and Profit Shifting|Multilateral Instrument]], consisting of ''15 Actions'' designed to be implemented domestically and through bilateral tax treaty provisions, were agreed at the [[2015 G20 Antalya summit]]. The OECD BEPS Multilateral Instrument ("MLI"), was adopted on 24 November 2016 and has since been signed by over 78 jurisdictions. It came into force in July 2018. Many tax havens opted–out from several of the Actions, including Action 12 (Disclosure of aggressive tax planning), which was considered onerous by corporations who use BEPS tools. [[File:Enda Kenny Feargal O'Rourke Taken at IBEC 2014 Conference Flickr.jpg|thumb|260px|Former Irish [[Taoiseach]] [[Enda Kenny]] (l), and PwC Partner [[Feargal O'Rourke]] (r) ''architect'' of two of the largest BEPS tools in the world, the [[Double Irish]] (including Microsoft, Google, Facebook, IBM, Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer, amongst many others), and the [[Ireland as a tax haven#Green Jersey|Green Jersey]] (as used by Apple in their Q1 2015 "[[leprechaun economics]]" restructuring in Ireland).{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-10-28/man-making-ireland-tax-avoidance-hub-globally-proves-local-hero| title=FEARGAL O'ROURKE: Man Making Ireland Tax Avoidance Hub Proves Local Hero | publisher=Bloomberg News|date=28 October 2013}}]] {{quote|Global legal firm [[Baker McKenzie]],{{Cite web| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/06/world/apple-taxes-jersey.html|quote=A key architect [for Apple] was [[Baker McKenzie]], a huge law firm based in Chicago. The firm has a reputation for devising creative offshore structures for multinationals and defending them to tax regulators. It has also fought international proposals for tax avoidance crackdowns.|title=After a Tax Crackdown, Apple Found a New Shelter for Its Profits | work = The New York Times|date=6 November 2017}} representing a coalition of 24 multinational US software firms, including Microsoft, lobbied [[Michael Noonan (Fine Gael politician)|Michael Noonan]], as [Irish] minister for finance, to resist the [OECD MLI] proposals in January 2017. In a letter to him the group recommended Ireland not adopt article 12, as the changes “will have effects lasting decades” and could “hamper global investment and growth due to uncertainty around taxation”. The letter said that “keeping the current standard will make Ireland a more attractive location for a regional headquarters by reducing the level of uncertainty in the tax relationship with Ireland’s trading partners”.|author=[[Irish Times]]. "Ireland resists closing corporation tax ‘loophole’" (10 November 2017){{Cite web|author=Jack Power|title = Ireland resists closing corporation tax ‘loophole’|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/ireland-resists-closing-corporation-tax-loophole-1.3286199|work=The Irish Times|date=10 November 2017}}}} The acknowledged ''architect'' of the largest ever global corporate BEPS tools (e.g. Google and Facebooks' Double Irish and Apple's Green Jersey), tax partner [[Feargal O'Rourke]] from [[PriceWaterhouseCoopers]] ("PwC), predicted in May 2015 that the OECD's MLI would be a success for the leading corporate tax havens, at the expense of the smaller, less developed, traditional [[tax havens]], whose BEPS tools were not sufficiently robust.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/scion-of-a-prominent-political-dynasty-who-gave-his-vote-to-accountancy-1.2203820?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fbusiness%2Ffinancial-services%2Fscion-of-a-prominent-political-dynasty-who-gave-his-vote-to-accountancy-1.2203820| title=Scion of a prominent political dynasty who gave his vote to accountancy| quote=Of the wider tax environment, O’Rourke thinks the OECD base-erosion and profit-shifting (BEPS) process is “very good” for Ireland. “If BEPS sees itself to a conclusion, it will be good for Ireland.”|work=The Irish Times|date=8 May 2015}} In August 2016, the [[Tax Justice Network]]'s Alex Cobham described the OECD's MLI as a failure due to the opt–outs and watering–down of individual BEPS Actions.{{cite web |first1=Alex |last1= Cobham |url=http://www.taxjustice.net/2016/08/24/us-treasury-tax-war-europe/ |quote=Second, it confirms (once again) that the OECD BEPS process has failed. |title=The US Treasury just declared tax war on Europe |date=24 August 2016 }} In December 2016, Cobham highlighted that one of the critical anti–BEPS Actions, full public ''country–by–country–reporting'' ("CbCr"), had been dropped due to lobbying by the U.S. multinationals.{{cite web|url=https://economia.icaew.com/news/december-2016/oecds-beps-measures-seriously-flawed|quote=The major problem, it says, has been the decision by the Organisation in 2013 when it came up with its standard on country–by–country reporting (CBCR) to give into intense lobbying, largely from US multinationals, and place limits on access to the data.|title=OECD's BEPs measures seriously flawed|publisher=economia|date=9 December 2016}} CbCr is the only way to conclusively observe the level of BEPS activitiy and OECD compliance in any country. In June 2017, a U.S. Treasury official explained that the reason why U.S. refused to sign up to the OECD's MLI, or any of its Actions, was because: "the U.S. tax treaty network has a low degree of exposure to base erosion and profit shifting issues".{{cite web|url=https://www.bna.com/treasury-official-explains-n73014453413/ | title=Treasury Official Explains Why U.S. Didn’t Sign OECD Super-Treaty | publisher=Bloomberg BNA | quote=The U.S. didn’t sign the groundbreaking tax treaty inked by 68 [later 70] countries in Paris June 7 [2017] because the U.S. tax treaty network has a low degree of exposure to base erosion and profit shifting issues", a U.S. Department of Treasury official said at a transfer pricing conference co–sponsored by Bloomberg BNA and [[Baker McKenzie]] in Washington |date=8 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.alston.com/en/insights/publications/2017/07/impact-of-mli-on-taxpayers|title=International Tax Advisory: Impact of the Multilateral Instrument on U.S. Taxpayers: Why Didn’t the United States Choose to Sign the MLI?|publisher=[[Alston & Bird]]|date=14 July 2014|quote=}} ==Impact of the TCJA== [[File:Ireland Trade Good Discrepancy (1995-2017).png|thumb|upright=1.4|Apple's Q1 2015 Irish quasi–[[tax inversion]] of USD 300 billon in IP, is the largest [[BEPS]] transaction in history, and double the blocked 2016 USD 160 billion Pfizer–Allergan Irish [[corporate inversion|inversion]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cfr.org/blog/tax-avoidance-and-irish-balance-payments|title=Tax Avoidance and the Irish Balance of Payments|publisher=[[Council on Foreign Relations]]|author1=[[Brad Setser]]|author2=Cole Frank|date=25 April 2018}} Due to Irish secrecy laws, the transaction was only confirmed in January 2018, and was labelled "[[Leprechaun economics]]" by Nobel Prize–winning economist, [[Paul Krugman]].]] {{see also|Ireland as a tax haven#Impact of TCJA}} {{see also|Double Irish arrangement#Effect of Tax Cuts and Jobs Act}} The [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]] ("TCJA") moved the U.S. from a "worldwide" corporate tax system to a hybrid{{efn|The TCJA system is described as ''hybrid'', because it still forces minimum U.S. tax rates on foreign income under the TCJA GILTI regime}} "territorial" tax system. The TCJA includes anti–BEPS tool regimes including the GILTI–tax and BEAT–tax regimes. It also contains its own BEPS tools, namely the FDII–tax regime.{{efn|The FDII regime allows U.S. multinationals to charge-out [[intellectual property]] ("IP") direct from the U.S., at a preferential 13.125% U.S. tax rate}} The TCJA could represent a major change in Washington's tolerance of U.S. multinational use of BEPS tools. Tax experts in early 2018 forecast the demise of the two major U.S. corporate tax havens, Ireland and Singapore, in the expectation that U.S. multinationals would no longer need foreign BEPS tools.{{cite web|url=https://harvardmagazine.com/2018/05/mihir-desai-tax-reform|title=Tax Reform: Round One|work=Harvard Magazine|author=[[Mihir A. Desai]]|date=June 2018}} However, by mid–2018, U.S. multinationals had not repatriated any BEPS tools,{{efn|This is not to be confused with the repatriation of the circa USD 1 trillion in offshore untaxed cash; these are the [[intellectual property]] ("IP") assets that U.S. multinationals house in locations like Ireland which are the ''raw materials'' for the BEPS tools. A repatriation of a major U.S. multinational BEPS tool would cause reverse–[[leprechaun economics]] events in various tax havens}} and the evidence is that they have increased exposure to corporate tax havens. In March–May 2018, Google committed to doubling its office space in Ireland,{{cite web|url=https://amp.independent.ie/business/commercial-property/google-to-pay-over-115m-to-buy-treasury-building-37154126.html|title=Google, Facebook and Salesforce.com dramatically expand their Dublin office hubs|date=26 July 2018|work=Irish Independent}} while in June 2018 it was shown that Microsoft is preparing to execute Apple's Irish BEPS tool, the "Green Jersey" (see [[Ireland as a tax haven#Technical issues with TCJA|Irish experience post–TCJA]]).{{cite web|url= https://www.businesspost.ie/news/irish-microsoft-firm-worth-100bn-ahead-merger-419721|title=Irish Microsoft firm worth $100bn ahead of merger|work=Sunday Business Post|date=24 June 2018}} In July 2018, one of Ireland's leading tax experts forecasted a potential boom in U.S. multinationals on–shoring their BEPS tools from the Caribbean to Ireland, and not to the U.S. as was expected after TCJA.{{cite web|url=http://economic-incentives.blogspot.com/2018/07/when-can-we-expect-next-wave-of-ip.html|title=When can we expect the next wave of IP onshoring?|quote=IP onshoring is something we should be expecting to see much more of as we move towards the end of the decade. Buckle up!|author=Seamus Coffey, [[Irish Fiscal Advisory Council]]|date=18 July 2018}} In May 2018, it was shown that the TCJA contains [[Ireland as a tax haven#Technical issues with TCJA|technical issues]] that incentivise these actions.{{cite web|url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/up-front/2018/05/25/6-ways-to-fix-the-tax-system-post-tcja/|title=6 ways to fix the tax system post TCJA|author=[[Ben Harris (economist)|Ben Harris]]|publisher=[[Brookings Institution]]|date=25 May 2018}} For example, by accepting Irish tangible, and intangible, capital allowances in the GILTI calculation, Irish BEPS tools like the "Green Jersey" enable U.S. multinationals to achieve ''U.S. effective tax rates'' of 0–3% via the TCJA's foreign ''participation relief'' system.{{cite web|URL=https://taxfoundation.org/treatment-foreign-profits-tax-cuts-jobs-act/|publisher=[[Tax Foundation]]|date=3 May 2018|title=A Hybrid Approach: The Treatment of Foreign Profits under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act}} There is debate as to whether these are drafting mistakes to be corrected, or concessions to enable U.S. multinationals to reduce their effective corporate tax rates to circa 10% (the Trump administration's original target).{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/79538ba6-a35b-11e7-b797-b61809486fe2|title=Donald Trump seeks to slash US corporate tax rate|date=27 September 2017|work=Financial Times|quote=Cutting the official corporate tax rate to 20 per cent from its present 35 per cent — a level that US companies say hurts them in global competition — would leave companies short of the 15 per cent Mr Trump promised as a candidate}} ==See also== *[[Tax haven]] *[[Conduit and Sink OFCs]] *[[James R. Hines Jr.]] *[[Gabriel Zucman]] *[[Ireland as a tax haven]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.oecd.org/tax/beps/ OECD BEPS Portal] * [https://www.ey.com/gl/en/services/tax/ey-beps-developments-tracker Ernst & Young BEPS Portal] * [https://home.kpmg.com/uk/en/home/services/tax/base-erosion-and-profit-shifting.html KPMG BEPS Portal] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS)}} [[Category:Competition (economics)]] [[Category:International business]] [[Category:International taxation]] [[Category:Pricing]] [[Category:Tax avoidance]] [[Category:Corporate tax avoidance]]

[[Martin Russell]] | released =2005 | runtime =142 minutes | country =Lebanon | language =Arabic |editing = Dana K. Trometer}} '''''Bosta''''' ([[English language|English]]: ''The Autobus'' [[Arabic language|Arabic]]: ''Bosta'' — بوسطة) is a 2005 [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] [[film]] by the director [[Philippe Aractingi]]. Bosta is a story of young Lebanese artists who meet again, after being separated, and tour different cities of [[Lebanon]] in an old bus, performing a techno version of the [[dabkeh]] that shocks conservatives, but moves forward towards the future. [[Simon Emmerson]] and [[Martin Russell]] from the group, [[Afro Celt Sound System]] composed original music for the [[dabkeh]] (dance) sequences and composed the film's underscore respectively.[http://www.psfilmfest.org/festival/film/detail.aspx?id=11801&FID=29 Bosta | 2007 Palm Springs International Film Festival | Philippe Aractingi | Lebanon] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212045145/http://www.psfilmfest.org/festival/film/detail.aspx?id=11801&FID=29 |date=February 12, 2007 }} Quoting from the official site:
''Bosta'' is a road musical that takes the audience on a wonderful journey across various Lebanese regions... a journey accompanied by a groundbreaking soundtrack and, of course, this truly pioneering dance, the electro-dabkeh.
''Bosta'' was the best selling film in Lebanon in 2006.[http://cinema.club-internet.fr/film/anecdote_gen_cfilm=121497.html AOL Neuf Cegetel - Club Internet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927185650/http://cinema.club-internet.fr/film/anecdote_gen_cfilm%3D121497.html |date=September 27, 2007 }} The movie was submitted as the official [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] entry in the [[79th Academy Awards|79th Academy Awards (Oscars)]] in the Best Foreign Language Film category.{{cite web |url=http://www.oscarguy.com/History/Oscars/79th/Foreign.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070213022935/http://www.oscarguy.com/History/Oscars/79th/Foreign.html |archivedate=2007-02-13 |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.bostathemovie.com/ Official website] *{{Imdb title|id=0497335|title=Bosta}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X4lEHsv6BBI Trailer of the movie] *[http://www.sonicinnovation.co.uk/music/bostasuite.m3u An edited suite of music from Martin Russell's underscore (streaming audio).]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} **[http://www.danatrometer.com/ Dana Trometer Editing Website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Bosta (Film)}} [[Category:2005 films]] [[Category:Lebanese films]] [[Category:Arabic-language films]] [[Category:2000s musical films]] {{Lebanon-film-stub}} {{Musical-film-stub}}

{{morereferences|date=November 2014}} '''Chain ganging''' is a term in the field of international relations describing the elevated probability for interstate conflict or conflagration due to several states having joined together in alliances or coalitions.
The agreed principles of such alliances typically include [[Mutual Defense Treaty|mutual defence clauses]] requiring that, in the case of one member state suffering military attack from another power, all members must declare hostilities against that offending power. The result of such an arrangement is an elevated probability for an international conflagration, since the case of an actor attacking another power would almost certainly trigger, whether intentionally or not, a multinational conflict potentially involving many more actors than the original two states which had attacked and been attacked, respectively. According to sworn agreements or treaties no member state has the option to refuse to participate in this involvement: once the states have agreed to the alliance, they are bound by obligation to join in the hostilities or conflagration as soon as they have begun in one state (though this obligation is not always honoured).
==Historical examples== An empirical example of the chain ganging dilemma is [[World War I]]. When [[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]] decided to part from the [[Triple Alliance (1882)|Triple Alliance]], both [[Austria-Hungary]] and [[German Empire|Germany]] were alone for the most part in [[Europe]] (though [[Kingdom of Bulgaria|Bulgaria]] and the [[Ottoman Empire]] joined Austria-Hungary and Germany to form the [[Central Powers]]), and surrounded by the [[Allies (World War I)|Allied Powers]]. The defeat of either of the two would severely weaken the remaining member. According to [[Kenneth Waltz]], "The defeat or defection of a major ally would have shaken the balance, each state was constrained to adjust its strategy and the use of its forces to the aims and fears of its partners."<ref>{{cite book|last = Waltz|first = Kenneth|title = Theory of International Politics|publisher = McGraw-Hill Humanities|year = 1979|isbn = 0-07-554852-6|page = 167}}</ref>
==Etymology== The term is a metaphor deriving from [[chain gang]]s, groups of people, usually prisoners or slaves, bound together with chains or other devices as they work or march. Like a real-life chain gang, the states joined together in a chain gang, according to bound obligation, have no option to refuse to follow along with the intent of the others. However, in reality, the members of a chain gang coalition can and sometimes do choose to refuse to acquiesce, in which case they may face international ostracism (at least from the other members of their former alliance), and possibly courtship on the part of rival coalitions. This is because, typically, few punitive actions exists in the realm of [[international law]] that can sufficiently compel a power to follow its obligations at all costs, and therefore, the incentives to breaking ranks can sometimes be rather high, especially when the state does not agree with the actions taken by the other members of its coalition.
==See also== *[[Bandwagoning]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:International relations]]
{{poli-term-stub}}

'''ECAPS''' is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] space company, established in 2000 by the [[Swedish Space Corporation]] (SSC) and [[Volvo Aero]] with the primary purpose of developing [[rocket propellant]]s safer than [[hydrazine]], but with the same application areas. The company was acquired in 2017 and is currently part of the Bradford group of space systems companies, which is itself part of the larger AIAC group of manufacturing companies
One of the developed propellants is [[HPGP]], a name for a propellant blend consisting primarily of [[ammonium dinitramide]], [[ammonia]], [[methanol]] and [[water]]. Another name for the propellant is LMP-103S, which refers to the specific blend. Propellant is currently being produced in [[Karlskoga]], Sweden with production of thruster systems primarily produced within Bradford facilities (which include ECAPS facilities) in [[Solna]], Sweden and [[Heerle]], Netherlands.
ECAPS HPGP systems have been used on the European [[PRISMA]] mission and is currently being used by [[Planet]] for its SkySat line of spacecraft. Twelve spacecraft to date have been launched with HPGP systems. HPGP is also planned to be used on the [[Lunar Flashlight]] and [[ArgoMoon]] missions to the [[Moon]], on [[Astroscale]] space debris removal spacecraft, on the [[U.S. Air Force]]'s [[STPSat-5]] technology demonstrator spacecraft and on the [[Astranis]] microGEO bus.
== References == * http://www.ecaps.space/ Official homepage

{{Infobox non-profit|name=Ehlers-Danlos Society|predecessor=Ehlers-Danlos National Foundation|purpose=Patient advocacy|website={{URL|https://www.ehlers-danlos.com}}|founder=Nancy Rogowski|key_people=[[Shane Robinson (politician)|Shane Robinson]]
[[Lara Bloom]]|formation=1985 (as Ehlers-Danlos National Foundation)
May 1, 2016 (as Ehlers-Danlos Society)|leader_title=International Executive Director|leader_name=[[Lara Bloom]]|status=Active|leader_title2=United States Executive Director|leader_name2=[[Shane Robinson (politician)|Shane Robinson]]|image=File:EhlersDanlosSociety.png}} The '''Ehlers-Danlos Society''' is an [[International organization|international]] [[non-profit|non-profit organization]] dedicated to patient support, scientific research, advocacy, and increasing awareness for the [[Ehlers-Danlos syndromes]] (EDS), hypermobility spectrum disorder (HSD), and related medical disorders.{{Cite web|url=https://health.usnews.com/wellness/articles/2016-11-11/ehlers-danlos-syndrome-more-than-just-stretchy-skin-and-bendy-joints|title=Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: More Than Just Stretchy Skin and Bendy Joints|last=Miller|first=Anna Medaris|date=2016-11-11|website=U.S. News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The society has organized multiple events around the world in an attempt to raise awareness for EDS. These events include a rally in Baltimore’s Inner Harbor, and a conference in India.{{Cite news|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2016/06/prweb13494815.htm|title=The Ehlers-Danlos Society to Hold Rally in Baltimore’s Inner Harbor to Promote Awareness of Genetic Disorder Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS)|work=PRWeb|access-date=2017-10-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2017/05/elastic-girl-living-ehlers-danlos-syndrome-170514115635143.html|title=The elastic girl: Living with Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome|last=O'Dell|first=Emily Jane|date=2017-06-05|website=Al Jazeera|access-date=2017-10-19}} The society also organizes symposiums dedicated to research on EDS.{{Cite web|url=http://fillmorecountyjournal.com/local-woman-raises-eds-awareness/|title=Local woman raises EDS awareness|last=Jeffers|first=Barb|date=2017-05-01|website=Fillmore County Journal|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-19}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/2016-international-symposium-may-3-6-2016/|title=2016 International Symposium - May 3–6, 2016|date=2016-03-10|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2017-10-19|language=en-US}} The 2016 symposium resulted in the reclassification of [[Classification of Ehlers–Danlos syndrome|Ehlers-Danlos subtypes]].{{Cite web|url=https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/6322/ehlers-danlos-syndromes|title=Ehlers-Danlos syndromes|website=Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center|publisher=National Institutes of Health|language=en|access-date=2017-10-19}} == History == The Ehlers-Danlos National Foundation (EDNF) was founded in 1985 by Nancy Rogowski. In 2013, they donated money to help fund the opening of a research center in [[Baltimore]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/coulter/ednf/prweb10728485.htm|title=Coulter Client Ehlers-Danlos National Foundation to Open Research Clinic in Baltimore|work=PRWeb|access-date=2017-10-19}} On May 1, 2016, in partnership with an international consortium of Ehlers-Danlos researchers, the EDNF became The Ehlers-Danlos Society.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/our-history/|title=Our History|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2017-10-19|language=en-US}} On September 7, 2017, the Ehlers-Danlos Society hosted a learning conference in Las Vegas.{{Cite web|url=https://lasvegassun.com/events/2017/sep/07/50108/|title=The Ehlers-Danlos Society Global Learning Conference 2017: Thursday, Sept. 7, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. -|website=Las Vegas Sun|language=en|access-date=2017-10-19}} == Leadership == There are two executive directors in the Ehlers-Danlos Society, one of which is the "International Executive Director" Lara Bloom, {{Cite news|url=http://www.eagletribune.com/news/pelham-schools-face-new-civil-rights-investigation/article_4e4a415d-7281-5ce3-bb7f-54d804020b15.html|title=Pelham schools face new civil rights investigation|last=Edelstein|first=Breanna|date=2017-08-20|work=Eagle-Tribune|access-date=2017-10-19|language=en}} and the other one is the "United States Executive Director", [[Shane Robinson (politician)|Shane Robinson]].{{Cite web|url=http://msa.maryland.gov/msa/mdmanual/06hse/html/msa15460.html|title=Shane Robinson, Maryland State Delegate|website=Maryland Manual On-Line|publisher=Maryland State Archives|access-date=2017-10-19}} === Board of Directors{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/our-people/#board|title=Our People|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-US}} === # Sandra Aiken Chack, Chair{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/sandra-chack/|title=Sandra Aiken Chack|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Susan Hawkins, Vice Chair{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/susan-hawkins/|title=Susan Hawkins|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # John Zonarich, Esq., Secretary{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/john-zonarich/|title=John B. Zonarich, Esq.|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Richard Malenfant, MBA, MPH{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/richard-malenfant/|title=Richard Malenfant, MBA, MPH|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Peter Cohl{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/peter-cohl/|title=Peter Cohl|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-US}} # Susan Haskel{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/susan-haskel/|title=Susan Haskel|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-US}} # Linda Neumann-Potash{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/linda-neumann-potash/|title=Linda Neumann-Potash|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-US}} # Dr. Jakob Rasmussen{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/jakob-rasmussen/|title=Dr. Jakob Rasmussen|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-US}} === Medical and Scientific Board === # Fransiska Malfait, M.D., Ph.D., Chair {{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/fransiska-malfait/|title=Fransiska Malfait, MD, PhD|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Clair Francomano, M.D., Ph.D., Vice Chair{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/clair-francomano/|title=Clair Francomano, MD, PhD|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Qasim Aziz, MBBS, FRCP, Ph.D.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/qasim-aziz/|title=Qasim Aziz, MBBS, FRCP, PhD|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Peter Byers, M.D.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/peter-byers/|title=Peter Byers, MD|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Marco Castori, M.D., Ph.D.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/marco-castori/|title=Marco Castori, MD, PhD|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Heidi Collins, M.D.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/heidi-collins/|title=Heidi Collins, MD|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Raymond Dalgleish, Ph.D.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/raymond-dalgleish/|title=Raymond Dalgleish, PhD|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Cecilia Giunta, Ph.D.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/cecilia-giunta/|title=Cecilia Giunta, PhD|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Rodney Grahame CBE, M.D., FRCP, FACP, FRSA{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/rodney-grahame/|title=Rodney Grahame CBE, MD, FRCP, FACP, FRSA|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Alan Hakim, MA, FRCP{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/alan-hakim/|title=Alan Hakim, MA, FRCP|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Fraser Cummins Henderson Sr., M.D.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/fraser-cummins-henderson/|title=Fraser Cummins Henderson Sr.|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Tomoki Kosho, M.D.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/tomoki-kosho/|title=Tomoki Kosho, MD|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Cathleen L. Raggio, M.D. {{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/cathy-raggio/|title=Cathy Raggio|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Jane Simmonds, MCSP, MMACP, FHEA{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/jane-simmonds/|title=Jane Simmonds, MCSP, MMACP, FHEA|work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Glenda Sobey, MB ChB, BSc Med (Hons), FC Derm{{Cite news|url=https://www.ehlers-danlos.com/glenda-sobey/|title=Glenda Sobey, MB ChB, BSc Med (Hons), FC Derm |work=The Ehlers-Danlos Society|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} # Brad Tinkle.
