{{Infobox Diplomatic Mission | name = Embassy of Turkey, Washington, D.C. | image = Embassy of Turkey, Washington, D.C. (2).jpg | address = 2525 [[Massachusetts Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Massachusetts Avenue]], [[Northwest, Washington, D.C.|N.W.]] | location = [[Washington, D.C.]] | coordinates = {{coord|38.91648|-77.05596|type:landmark_region:US-DC|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | ambassador = | website = [http://www.washington.emb.mfa.gov.tr/ washington.emb.mfa.gov.tr] }} [[File:Embassy of Turkey, Washington, D.C. (3).jpg|238px|thumb|The [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk (Embassy of Turkey, Washington, D.C.)|statue of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]] in Turkish Embassy, Washington D.C.]] The '''Embassy of Turkey in Washington, D.C.''' is the [[diplomatic mission]] of the [[Turkey|Republic of Turkey]] to the [[United States]]. It is located at 2525 [[Massachusetts Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Massachusetts Avenue]], [[Northwest, Washington, D.C.|Northwest]] in the [[Embassy Row]] neighborhood.
The chancery is housed in a new building, inaugurated by Turkish [[President of Turkey|President]] [[Süleyman Demirel]] on April 23, 1999. Designed by [[Shalom Baranes Associates]], it reflects aspects of Turkish [[vernacular architecture]] while harmonizing with the styles of the [[Kalorama, Washington, D.C.|Sheridan-Kalorama]] neighborhood.
Previously, the embassy had been housed in a mansion farther south, at [[Sheridan Circle]] and 23rd Street, N.W. The building today serves as the Turkish ambassador's residence. It was originally built for [[Edward Hamlin Everett]], a bottling millionaire, in 1915. The Everett House was designed by [[George Oakley Totten, Jr.]], a Washingtonian who had spent a brief period in Turkey as the official architect for [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[Sultan]] [[Abdul Hamid II]]. The Turkish government leased the building in 1932 and purchased it four years later.
==2017 violent clashes== {{Main article|Clashes at the Turkish Ambassador's Residence in Washington, D.C.}} On May 16, 2017, armed Turkish security forces attacked pro Kurdish protesters demonstrating on behalf of the North American Kurdish Alliance outside the ambassador's residence during a visit by President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]], forcing intervention by the [[Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fandos|first1=Nicholas|last2=Mele|first2=Christopher|title=Erdogan Security Forces Launch ‘Brutal Attack’ on Washington Protesters, Officials Say|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/17/us/turkish-embassy-protest-dc.html|accessdate=19 May 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=18 May 2017|page=A17}}</ref> On March 31, 2016, Turkish security forces had attacked protesters and journalists further down [[Embassy Row]] during a speech by President Erdoğan at the [[Brookings Institution]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kirişci|first1=Kemal|title=Turkey’s downward spiral and the scuffles at Erdoğan’s Brookings speech|url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2016/04/04/turkeys-downward-spiral-and-the-scuffles-at-erdogans-brookings-speech/|accessdate=19 May 2017|work=[[Brookings Institution]]|date=19 May 2017}}</ref>
== Ambassadors == * [[Münir Ertegün]] (1934–1944) * [[Feridun Cemal Erkin|Feridun Erkin]] (1948–1955) * [[Suat Hayri Ürgüplü]] (1959–1960) * [[Melih Esenbel]] (1960–1967) * [[Melih Esenbel]] (1975–1979) * [[Şükrü Elekdağ]] (1979–1989) * [[Nüzhet Kandemir]] (1989–1998) * [[Baki İlkin]] (1998–2001) * [[Faruk Loğoğlu]] (2001–2006) * [[Nabi Şensoy]] (2006–2010) * [[Namık Tan]] (2010–2014) * [[Serdar Kılıç]] (2014–present)

{{Infobox school |name = Engelsborg School |native_name = Engelsborgskolen |image = Engelsborgskolen 01.jpg |image_size = 300px |streetaddress = Engelsborgvej 66, 2800 [[Kongens Lyngby]] |coordinates = {{coord|55|45|57.16|N|12|29|29.45|E}} |schoolnumber = |principal = Bettina Kallenbach |staff = |gender = Co-ed |lower_age = 6 |upper_age = 16 |schooltype = Public |type = Elementary |enrolment = 1,000 (2017) |grades = Reception - Year 10 |language = Danish |established = {{start date and age|1909}} |homepage = [http://engelsborgskolen.skoleporten.dk/sp Website] }} '''Engelsborgskolen''' is a public primary school in the western part of [[Kongens Lyngby]], [[Lyngby-Taarbæk Municipality]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. Inaugurated in 1909, it is the oldest active school in Lyngby-Taarbæk. It has been used as a location in a number of films and television series, including as Little Per's school in the original [[Father of Four]] films.
==History== [[File:Engelsborgskolen.jpg|thumb|left|Engelsborgskolen]] The first school in Kongens Lyngby, a ''[[rytterskole]]'', was built next to the village pond in 1722. Ut was expanded with a two-storey brick building in 1882. The old rytterskole building from 1722 was replaced by a new residence for the school principal in 1904. The local population was growing steadily and Lyngby School soon became too small. It was therefore decided to built a new school at Engelsborgsvej.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thorshoj.dk/Rytterskoler_Koebenhavn.HTM|title=Rytterskolerne i Københavns Rytterdistriktn|language=Danish|website=Rytterskoler_Koebenhavn.HTM|accessdate=1 June 2017}}</ref>
The school was founded on 30 January 1909. Exams were introduced in 1918.<ref name=danskefilm>{{cite web|url=https://danskefilm.dk/lokation.php?id=173|title=Engelsborgskolen|language=Danish|website=danskefilm.dk|accessdate=1 June 2017}}</ref> The school has later been expanded several times, for instance with the construction of a new main building in 1935 and again in 1978. The school was refurbished and expanded by Rubow Arkitekter in 2008..
==Premises== Yje new main building from 1935 contains classrooms for the older students. The old main building contains science rooms and is also home to the school dentist. Building B from 1978 and contains workshops and classrooms for mid-level students. Building H contains administration and facilities for teachers. A new sports hall was built in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://engelsborgskolen.skoleporten.dk/sp/263693/foreside?pageId=c5ae43e8-afc5-4da5-9bf9-878801380726|title=Om skolen|language=Danish|publisher=Engelsborgskolen|accessdate=1 June 2017}}</ref>
==In popular culture== Engelsborgskolen has been used for all schoolyard scenes in the seven original ''[[Far til fire]]'' (''Father of Four'') film in the period 1953 to 1961. The school has also been used as a location in the films ''[[Lise kommer til byen]]'' (1947), ''[[Vejrhanen]]'' (1952), ''[[Sunes familie]]'' (1997) and ''[[Bølle Bob og Smukke Sally]]'' (2005) as well as in the [[TV 2 (Denmark)|TV2]] [[Nordic Christmas calendar|Christmas calendar]] ''[[Brødrene Mortensens jul]]'' (1998,2002).<ref name=danskefilm/>
==Further reading== * ''På en bakke i vest. Engelsborgskolen 1909-1984''

{{unreferenced|date=August 2012}} '''Estonian Swedish''' ({{lang-sv|estlandssvenska}}, {{lang-et|rannarootsi keel}}) describes the eastern dialects of [[Swedish language|Swedish]] that were spoken in the formerly Swedish-populated areas of [[Estonia]] (locally known as ''[[Aiboland]]'') on the islands of [[Ormsö]] (Vormsi), [[Ösel]] (Saaremaa), [[Hiiumaa|Dagö]] (Hiiumaa) and [[Runö]] (Ruhnu), and the peninsula (former island) of [[Nuckö]] (Noarootsi), by the local Estonian Swedes.
Until the evacuation of the [[Estonian Swedes]] near the end of [[World War II]], both Swedish and [[Estonian language|Estonian]] were commonly spoken on the named islands. After Estonia's reestablishment of independence following the fall of the Soviet Union, Estonian Swedish experienced a revival, with courses in the language being offered on Dagö and Ösel.
Estonian Swedish comprises a number of sub-dialects, for example ''nuckömål'' and ''rågömål''.
An example of the ''nuckömål'' dialect from the ''[[Nordisk familjebok]]'', compared with standard modern Swedish:
:''Stick tälknin i stolpan o hälvtor stolpan topa kalkan, säte Halmen o Hälma färe kalkan o ker te Nuckö toka.''
Standard Swedish:
:''Stick täljkniven i stolpen och vält stolpen på kälken, sätt Hjälmen och Hjälma för kälken och kör till Nuckö.''
== See also == * [[Swedish language]] * [[Swedish dialects]] * [[Standard Swedish]]
{{Swedish language}}
[[Category:Swedish dialects]] [[Category:Languages of Estonia]]

'''Germa''' ({{lang-ar|جرمة}}), known in ancient times as '''''Garama''''', is an archaeological site in [[Libya]]. It was the capital of the [[Garamantian Kingdom]].
The Garamantes were a [[Berbers|Berber]] people living in the [[Fezzan]] in the northeastern [[Sahara Desert]]. Garamantian power climaxed during the second and the third centuries [[Common Era|AD]], often in conflict with the [[Roman Empire]] to the north. Garama had a population of some four thousand and another six thousand living in villages within a 5 km radius.
The Garamantes often conducted raids across Rome's African frontier, the ''[[Limes Tripolitanus]]'', and retreat back to the safety of the desert. In 203 the [[Roman Emperor]] [[Septimius Severus]] launched a campaign deep into the Sahara, capturing Garama, but he abandoned it soon after.<ref>Birley, Anthony. ''Septimius Severus, the African emperor''. (2000), p. 153</ref>
The city was conquered by [[Uqba ibn Nafi]] in 49 [[Hijri year|A.H.]] (c. 669).<ref>Salem Mohammed ez Zawam, "Mu’jam al Amakin al Jughrafiya fi Libia", Dar wa Maktabat ash Sha’b, Misratah, 2005, p.51.</ref>
Archaeological work at Germa has most recently been conducted by Prof. [[David Mattingly (author)|David Mattingly]]'s Fazzan Project, which has continued the work of Charles Daniels and Mohammed Ayoub. The Fazzan Project is about to publish the second of four planned volumes based on its work.
==See also== *[[Berber people|Berber]] *[[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] *[[Green Sahara]]

{{Unreferenced|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Netherlands}} "Hemel en aarde" | image = [[File:Edsilia - Hemel en aarde.jpg|200px]] | caption = | year = 1998 | country = Netherlands | artist = [[Edsilia Rombley]] | as = Edsilia | with = | language = Dutch | languages = | composer = [[Eric van Tijn]], [[Jochem Fluitsma]] | lyricist = Eric van Tijn, Jochem Fluitsma | conductor = Dick Bakker | place = 4th | points = 150 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1998nl from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Niemand heeft nog tijd | prev_link = Niemand heeft nog tijd | next = One Good Reason | next_link = One Good Reason (song) }} '''"Hemel en aarde"''' ("Heaven and earth") was the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1998]], performed in [[Dutch language|Dutch]] by [[Edsilia Rombley|Edsilia]].
The song is a moderately up-tempo ballad, with Edsilia describing her feelings on discovering love in what was seemingly an unexpected place. She tells her lover that "Heaven and earth are opening/When you touch me", as well as singing that she "never wanted to believe" that such a thing was possible.
The song was recorded in English as "Walking On Water".
The song was performed eighteenth on the night (following [[Cyprus]]' [[Michael Hajiyanni]] with "[[Genesis (Michalis Hatzigiannis song)|Genesis]]" and preceding [[Sweden]]'s [[Jill Johnson]] with "[[Kärleken är]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 150 points, placing 4th in a field of 25. This was the Netherlands' best result in the contest since their win in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1975|1975]], until [[The Common Linnets]] reached a second place in [[Eurovision Song Contest 2014|2014]] with their song "[[Calm After the Storm]]".
It was succeeded as [[Netherlands in the Eurovision Song Contest|Dutch representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1999|1999 Contest]] by [[Marlayne]] with "[[One Good Reason (song)|One Good Reason]]".
The [[song]] has also been covered by artist [[Ruth Jacott]].
==Hemel-en-Aarde== There is a valley just beyond Hermanus (South Africa) called the Hemel-en-Aarde valley. Some of the most southern vineyards in South Africa are found here.
{{Netherlands in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1998}}

{{Other uses|Hey Mama (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox song | name = Hey, Mamma! | cover = Hey_Mamma_-_SunStroke_Project.jpeg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[SunStroke Project]] | album = | released = {{start date|2017|02|06|df=y}} | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[Electronic dance music|EDM]]|[[electropop]]}} | length = {{duration|m=2|s=59}} | label = Ragoza Music | writer = {{hlist|SunStroke Project| Mihail Cebotarenco}} | producer = | prev_title = Dam Dam Dam | prev_year = 2016 | next_title = Sun Gets Down | next_year = 2017 }} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Moldova}} "Hey, Mamma!" | image = | caption = | year = 2017 | country = Moldova | artist = [[SunStroke Project]] | language = English | composer = {{Hlist|SunStroke Project|Mihail Cebotarenco}} | lyricist = {{Hlist|Alina Galetskaya}} | conductor = | place = 3rd | points = 374 | place_semi = 2nd | points_semi = 291 | prev = Falling Stars | prev_year = 2016 | prev_link = Falling Stars (Lidia Isac song) | next = My Lucky Day | next_year = 2018 | next_link = My Lucky Day (DoReDoS song) }} "'''Hey, Mamma!'''" (also "'''Hey Mamma'''") is a song written and performed by Moldovan group [[SunStroke Project]]. The song was released as a digital download on 6 February 2017 through Ragoza Music. It [[Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest 2017|represented Moldova]] in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017]].{{cite web|last1=Herbert|first1=Emily|title=Moldova: SunStroke Project to Kyiv|url=https://eurovoix.com/2017/02/25/moldova-sunstroke-project-kyiv/|website=eurovoix.com|publisher=Eurovoix|date=25 February 2017|accessdate=25 February 2017}} ==Eurovision Song Contest== {{Main article|Moldova in the Eurovision Song Contest 2017}} SunStroke Project were confirmed to be taking part in ''O melodie pentru Europa 2017'', Moldova's national selection for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017]] on 18 January 2017.{{cite web|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|title=MOLDOVA: 40 SONGS SUBMITTED FOR O MELODIE PENTRU EUROPA 2017|url=https://eurovoix.com/2017/01/18/moldova-40-songs-submitted-o-melodie-pentru-europa-2017/|website=eurovoix.com|accessdate=21 January 2017|date=18 January 2017}} They were later confirmed to have qualified to the semi-finals after a live audition on 20 January.{{cite web|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2017/01/21/moldova-14-acts-advance-semifinal-live-auditions/166568/|title=MOLDOVA: 14 ACTS ADVANCE TO SEMI-FINAL AFTER LIVE AUDITIONS|date=21 January 2017|last=Honciuc|first=Bogdan|publisher=Wiwibloggs|website=wiwibloggs.com}} They won the jury vote in the semi-final, held on 24 February, and qualified directly for the final.{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2017/02/24/moldova-select-artists-tomorrows-final/|title=MOLDOVA SELECT ARTISTS FOR TOMORROW’S FINAL|date=24 February 2017|publisher=Eurovoix|website=eurovoix.com|last=Halliwell|first=Jamie}} During the final, held on 25 February, they placed second with the juries and first with the televoters, effectively winning the tiebreak and being declared the winner. Moldova competed in the second half of the first semi-final for the Eurovision Song Contest and went through to the Grand Final.{{Cite web|last=Jordan|first=Paul|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=kyiv_to_host_eurovision_2017|title=Kyiv to host Eurovision 2017!|date=9 September 2016|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=11 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Jordan|first1=Paul|title=Semi-Final Allocation Draw on Monday, pots revealed|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=semi-final_allocation_draw_on_monday_pots_revealed|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=25 January 2016|date=21 January 2016}} In the Grand Final, it finished third overall on a total of 374 points, which is Moldova's best result in the Contest to date. ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Digital download{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/no/album/hey-mamma-single/id1199611703|title=Hey Mamma - Single|website=iTunes|accessdate=25 February 2017}} | title1 = Hey Mamma | note1 = radio edit | length1 = 2:59 | title2 = Hey Mamma | note2 = karaoke version | length2 = 2:59 }} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! Chart (2017) ! Peak

revision.text:
<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{double image|right|Flag of Bosnia and Herzegovina.svg|224|Coat of arms of Bosnia and Herzegovina.svg|98|The [[Flag of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]|The [[Coat of arms of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]}} [[image:LocationBosniaAndHerzegovina.png|thumb|The location of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]]] [[image:Bosnia and Hercegovina map.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Bosnia and Herzegovina:
'''[[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]''' – country in Southwestern Europe, on the Balkan Peninsula. It comprises two autonomous entities: the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Republika Srpska, with a third region, the Brčko District, governed under local government. The country is home to three ethnic groups: Bosniaks are the largest group of the three, with Serbs second and Croats third.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
==General reference== [[image:Bosnia and Herzegovina-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]]] * Pronunciation: {{IPAc-en|audio=En-us-Bosnia.ogg|ˈ|b|ɒ|z|n|i|ə|...|ˌ|h|ɜːr|t|s|ə|ˈ|ɡ|oʊ|v|ᵻ|n|ə}} {{respell|BOZ|nee|ə|_|...|_|HURT|sə|GOH|vin|ə}} or {{IPAc-en|ˌ|h|ɜːr|t|s|ə|ɡ|oʊ|ˈ|v|iː|n|ə}} {{respell|HURT|sə|goh|VEE|nə}};<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/bosnia-and-herzegovina |title=Bosnia and Herzegovina – Definition of Bosnia and Herzegovina at |publisher=Yourdictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-25}}</ref> * Common English country name: [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * Official English country name: [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages| ]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states| ]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Bosnian (disambiguation)|Bosnian]], [[Herzegovinian (disambiguation)|Herzegovinian]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[ISO country codes]]: BA, BIH, 070 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:BA]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.ba]]
== Geography of Bosnia and Herzegovina == [[image:Dinarisches Gebirge Topo.png|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] and adjacent areas]]
[[Geography of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * Bosnia and Herzegovina is: a [[Nation state|country]] * Location: ** [[Eastern Hemisphere]] ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] *** [[Eurasia]] **** [[Europe]] ***** [[Southern Europe]] ****** [[Balkans]] (also known as "Southeastern Europe") ** [[Time zone]]: [[Central European Time]] ([[UTC+01]]), [[Central European Summer Time]] ([[UTC+02]]) ** [[Extreme points of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] *** High: [[Maglić mountain|Maglić]] {{convert|2386|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[Adriatic Sea]] 0 m ** Land boundaries: 1,538 km ::{{Flag|Croatia}} 932 km ::{{Flag|Serbia}} 357 km ::{{Flag|Montenegro}} 249 km ** Coastline: [[Adriatic Sea]] 20 km * [[Population of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]: 3,981,239(2007) - [[List of countries by population|126th most populous country]] * * [[Area of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]: {{convert|51197|km2|sqmi}} - [[List of countries and outlying territories by area|127th largest country]] * [[:commons:Atlas of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Atlas of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]

{{Infobox company | name = Panrusgáz Gas Trading Plc.
Panrusgáz Gázkereskedelmi Zrt. | logo = | caption = | type = private | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{start date|1994|10|01}} | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Budapest]] | location_country = [[Hungary]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Alexey Zaytsev (Director-General) | industry = oil and gas | products = natural gas | services = importing and distribution of natural gas | revenue = [[Image:Green Arrow Up.svg|12px]] US$2.6 billion (2007) | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 270 (2007) | parent = [[Gazprom]] | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.panrusgaz.hu/en/ceginf.htm www.panrusgaz.hu] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Panrusgáz''' is a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] [[natural gas|natural gas company]] responsible for the import of [[natural gas]] from [[Russia]] mainly [[Gazprom]]. The company sold 8.8 billion cubic meter of [[natural gas]] in [[Hungary]] in 2006. It was placed fourth on the Hungarian business weekly [[Heti Világgazdaság]] top-500 list of Hungarian companies by 2008 revenue of HUF 781 billion. {{cite news | newspaper = Budapest Business Journal | url= http://bbjonline.hu/?col=1000&id=51288 | title= MOL again leads HVG list of top 500 | date=2010-01-07 | accessdate=2010-07-22}} The company is owned by [[Gazprom Export]], [[E.ON| E.ON Ruhrgas International AG]], and [[Centrex Europe Energy & Gas AG|Centrex Hungária Zrt.]] It was established in 1994 as a joint venture of Gazprom and Hungarian gas company [[MOL Group|MOL]]. In January 2006, MOL's shares were acquired by German energy company [[E.ON]]. {{cite news | newspaper = [[Handelsblatt]] | url= https://www.handelsblatt.com/unternehmen/industrie/eon-macht-uebernahme-in-ungarn-perfekt;1017508 | title= Eon macht Übernahme in Ungarn perfekt |trans-title=Eon makes perfect acquisition in Hungary | language = German | date=2006-01-13 | accessdate=2010-07-22}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.panrusgaz.hu/en/ceginf.htm}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Panrusgaz}} [[Category:Gazprom subsidiaries]] [[Category:Oil and gas companies of Hungary]] {{petroleum-company-stub}} {{hungary-stub}} {{Europe-company-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Politique étrangère''' is the oldest French [[Academic journal|journal]] dedicated to the study of [[international relations]]. Created in 1936 by the French Council on Foreign Relations, this [[quarterly]] was taken over and published by the [[Institut français des relations internationales]] — French Institute for International Relations — when it was founded in 1979.
Open to world debates, Politique étrangère is the first distributor of French analysis for foreign countries. Politique étrangère is a long-term reference for academics, opinion leaders and members of civil society. It aims at highlighting all the key elements as to foreign affairs and offering deep analyses of today's international context.
Each edition offers at least two dossiers about an event or an aspect of the international debate, as well as several articles deciphering the emerging issues. Politique étrangère also places great interest in the latest French and foreign publications dealing with international relations.
We can mention [[Raymond Aron]], [[André Beaufre]], [[Jacques Berque]], [[Henry Kissinger]], [[Claude Lévi-Strauss]], [[Louis Massignon]] or even [[Jean-Paul Sartre]] among the authors who wrote articles for Politique étrangère.
== Editorial staff == * Director of publication: Thierry de Montbrial * Editors in Chief: Dominique David, Marc Hecker * Editorial board: Denis Bauchard, Bernard Cazes, Etienne de Durand, Thomas Gomart, Jolyon Howorth, Ethan Kapstein, Jean Klein, Jacques Mistral, Khadija Mohsen-Finan, Dominique Moïsi, Philippe Moreau Defarges, Eliane Mossé, Françoise Nicolas, Valérie Niquet, Hans Stark * Scientific Committee: Thierry de Montbrial, Hélène Carrère d’Encausse, Jean-Claude Casanova, Dominique Chevallier, Gérard Conac, Jean-Luc Domenach, Jean-Marie Guéhenno, François Heisbourg, Jacques Lesourne, Jean-Pierre Rioux, Pierre Rosanvallon, Olivier Roy, Jacques Rupnik, Georges-Henri Soutou, Maurice Vaïsse, Alain Vernay
== External links == * Presentation of Politique étrangère on the IFRI website [http://www.ifri.org/?page=pe_presentation&&lang=uk] * Wikipedia page of Ifri [[:fr:Institut français des relations internationales]] * Official blog of Politique étrangère [http://politique-etrangere.com] * Politique étrangère on the Cairn.info portal [http://www.cairn.info] * Politique étrangère on the Persée.fr portal [https://web.archive.org/web/20110224063324/http://www.persee.fr/web/guest/home] * Politique étrangère on the France Diplomatie website [http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/enjeux-internationaux/chercheurs-et-historiens/la-pensee-francaise/article/ifri]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Politique etrangere}} [[Category:International relations]] [[Category:French-language journals]]

{{Infobox Union |name= SGB/USS |country= [[Switzerland]] |affiliation= [[International Trade Union Confederation|ITUC]], [[ETUC]], [[TUAC]] |members= 385,000 |full_name= Swiss Trade Union Confederation |native_name= Schweizerischer Gewerkschaftsbund
Union Syndicale Suisse
Unione Sindacale Svizzera |image= [[File:SGB logo.png]] |founded= 1880 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Berne]], Switzerland |people= [[Paul Rechsteiner]], president |website= |footnotes= }} The '''Swiss Trade Union Confederation''' (SGB) is the largest [[national trade union center]] in [[Switzerland]]. It was founded in 1880 and represents 385,000 members in its affiliated unions. The SGB has close ties with the [[Social Democratic Party of Switzerland]] (SPS). [[Ruth Dreifuss]], the former [[President of the Swiss Confederation|President of the Confederation]], and former member of the [[Swiss Federal Council]], was previously an SGB official. The SGB is affiliated with the [[International Trade Union Confederation]], and the [[European Trade Union Confederation]]. It is also a member of the [[Trade Union Advisory Committee to the OECD]]. ==References== *{{cite book | year = 2005 | title = Trade Unions of the World | editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]] et al., | edition = 6th | publisher = John Harper Publishing | location = London, UK | isbn = 0-9543811-5-7 }} ==External links== * [http://www.uss.ch USS] official site (in French) * [http://www.sgb.ch SGB] official site (in German) {{Portal|Organized labour}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Trade unions in Switzerland]] [[Category:International Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:European Trade Union Confederation]] [[Category:Trade Union Advisory Committee to the OECD]] [[Category:1880 establishments in Switzerland]] [[Category:Organisations based in Bern]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1880]] [[Category:Swiss Climate Alliance]] {{Europe-trade-union-stub}} {{Switzerland-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-168 | image = GPS-IIR.jpg | image_caption = A Block IIR GPS satellite | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 2003-010A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=2003-010A|title=Navstar 52|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=11 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 27704 | mission_duration = 10 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block IIR]] | spacecraft_bus = [[AS-4000]] | manufacturer = [[Lockheed Martin]] | launch_mass = {{convert|2032|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|31 March 2003, 22:09:01|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II]] 7925-9.5,}} D297 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|SLC-17A]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_slot = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|20063|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20433|km}} | orbit_inclination = 54.9 degrees | orbit_period = 720.64 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-168''', also known as '''GPS IIR-9''' and '''GPS SVN-45''', is an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which forms part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the ninth [[GPS Block IIR|Block IIR]] GPS satellite to be launched, out of thirteen in the original configuration, and twenty one [[GPS Block IIRM|overall]]. It was built by [[Lockheed Martin]], using the [[AS-4000]] [[satellite bus]]. USA-168 was launched at 22:09:01 UTC on 31 March 2003, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D297, flying in the 7925-9.5 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Space Launch Complex 17A]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} and placed USA-168 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37FM]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2r.htm|title=GPS-2R (Navstar-2R)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=11 July 2012}} By 3 April 2003, USA-168 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|20063|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20433|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 720.64 minutes, and 54.9 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} It is used to broadcast the PRN 21 signal, and operates in slot 3 of plane D of the GPS constellation. The satellite has a mass of {{convert|2032|kg}}, and a design life of 10 years. As of 2012 it remains in service. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 2003}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2003]] [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

{{for|the airports located in Oklahoma City|Wiley Post Airport|Will Rogers World Airport}} {{Infobox airport | name = Wiley Post–Will Rogers International Airport | image = BRW-g.jpg | image-width = 250 | IATA = BRW | ICAO = PABR | FAA = BRW | type = Public | owner = State of Alaska DOT&PF - Northern Region | operator = | city-served = | location = [[Utqiagvik, Alaska]] | elevation-f = 44 | elevation-m = 13 | coordinates = {{coord|71|17|08|N|156|45|58|W|type:airport|display=title,inline}} | website = | | | pushpin_map = Alaska | pushpin_mapsize = 250 | pushpin_map_caption = Location of Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport | pushpin_label = '''PABR''' | pushpin_label_position = bottom | built = | r1-number = 7/25 | r1-length-f = 7,100 | r1-length-m = 2,164 | r1-surface = Asphalt | stat2-header = Based Aircraft | stat2-data = 8 | stat-year = 2015 | stat1-header = Aircraft Operations | stat1-data = 12,010 (2014) | stat3-header = Passengers | stat3-data = 88,840 | stat4-header = Freight | stat4-data = 24,000,000 lbs | footnotes = Source: [[Federal Aviation Administration]]{{FAA-airport|ID=BRW|use=PU|own=PU|site=50054.3*A}}, effective January 5, 2017 }} '''Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport''', {{airport codes|BRW|PABR|BRW}} often referred to as '''Post/Rogers Memorial''' is a public [[airport]] located in [[Utqiagvik]], the largest city and borough seat of the [[North Slope Borough, Alaska|North Slope Borough]] of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Alaska]].{{cite web | author= | title=BRW - Barrow, Alaska (Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport)| url=http://gc.kls2.com/airport/BRW | work=Great Circle Mapper | date=7 June 2012 | accessdate=7 June 2012}} The airport is owned by the state. Situated on the [[Chukchi Sea]] at a [[latitude]] of 71.29°N, the airport is the farthest north of any in US territory. The airport is named after American humorist [[Will Rogers]] and aviator [[Wiley Post]], both of whom died about {{convert|9|mi|abbr=on}} away at [[Point Barrow]] in a [[Rogers-Post Site|1935 airplane crash]].{{cite web|author= |title=About Barrow |url=http://www.cityofbarrow.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5&Itemid=13 |publisher=City of Barrow |year=2012 |accessdate=2 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110725173010/http://www.cityofbarrow.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5&Itemid=13 |archivedate=25 July 2011 |df= }} [[File:AlaskaAirlinesinBarrow1207.jpg|thumb|right|[[Alaska Airlines]] [[Boeing 737|737-400]] [[Combi aircraft|combi]] aircraft at Post/Rogers Memorial Airport, December 2007. Note that it is [[twilight]]. Even though the sun does not rise in December, it gets close enough to the horizon to provide illumination.]] [[File:BRW_AK_Airport.jpg|thumb|Utqiagvik AK airport from the unpaved street]] [[File:Polar bear at barrow airport.jpg|thumb|Polar bear at Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport, 2003]] ==Facilities and aircraft== Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport has one [[asphalt]] paved [[runway]] (7/25) measuring {{convert|7100|x|150|ft|abbr=on}}. For the 12-month period ending January 11, 2011, the airport had 12,010 aircraft operations, an average of 33 per day: 50% [[air taxi]], 37% [[general aviation]], 12% scheduled commercial and fewer than 1% military. At that time there were 8 aircraft based at this airport: 1 jet, 3 helicopters, 1 multi-engine, and 3 single-[[aircraft engine|engine]].{{cite web | author= | title=Wiley Post-Will Rogers Memorial Airport, Barrow, Alaska, USA | url=http://www.airnav.com/airport/PABR | work=Airnav | date=31 May 2012 | accessdate=7 June 2012}} ==Airlines and destinations== ===Passenger=== {{Airport destination list | [[Alaska Airlines]] | [[Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport|Anchorage]], [[Deadhorse Airport|Deadhorse]], [[Fairbanks International Airport|Fairbanks]]{{cite web | author=Alaska Airlines | title=Flight Timetable | format=PDF | url=http://www.trvlink.com/download/as/ASschedules.pdf}} (retrieved January 8, 2017) | [[Ravn Alaska]] | [[Atqasuk Edward Burnell Sr. Memorial Airport|Atqasuk]], [[Nuiqsut Airport|Nuiqsut]], [[Point Lay LRRS Airport|Point Lay]], [[Wainwright Airport (Alaska)|Wainwright]]{{cite web | author=Ravn Alaska | title=Destinations | format= | url=https://www.flyravn.com/flying-with-ravn/route-map/}} (retrieved January 8, 2017) }} ==Statistics== {{Bar graph | title = Carrier shares: (Dec 2015 - Nov 2016) | bar_width = 20 | width_units = em | label_type = Carrier   | data_type = Passengers (arriving and departing) | data_max = 70,000 | label1 = [[Alaska Airlines]] | data1 = 69,880 | comment1 = 79.45% | label2 = [[Hageland Aviation|Hageland]] | data2 = 18,080 | comment2 = 20.55% }} ===Top Destinations=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: 95%" width= align= |+ '''Busiest routes from BRW
